revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name= The American–Israeli Cooperative Enterprise |logo=American Israeli Cooperative Enterprise logo.jpg |logo_size=200px |type= |founded_date=1993{{cite book|author1=Arnold Dashefsky|author2=Ira M. Sheskin|title=American Jewish Year Book 2015: The Annual Record of the North American Jewish Communities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gaqFCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA525|date=3 February 2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-319-24505-8|pages=525–}} |founder=[[Mitchell Bard]] |location=[[Chevy Chase (Washington, D.C.)]], Maryland |origins= |key_people=Howard Rosenbloom (President)
Mitchell G. Bard (Executive Director)
Dr. Arthur Bard (Vice President)
Dr. Daniel Lieber (Secretary)
Norman Goldstein (Treasurer){{cite web | title=Board of Directors | website=Jewish Virtual Library | url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/board-of-directors | access-date=December 31, 2017}} |area_served= |focus= |method= |revenue= |endowment= |num_employees= |owner= |Non-profit_slogan= |homepage= }} '''The American–Israeli Cooperative Enterprise''' ('''AICE''') is a non-profit [[501(c)(3)]] U.S.-based organization established in 1993 "to strengthen the [[Israel–United States relations|U.S.-Israel relationship]]."{{cite web | title=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise | website=Crunchbase | url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/american-israeli-cooperative-enterprise | access-date=December 31, 2017}} ==Organization structure== AICE's goals are enhancing the understanding and appreciation of Israel through social and educational programs in the United States, disseminating information about Israel; aiding efforts of students and faculty attempting to counteract [[anti-Zionist]] rhetoric and activities; promoting the study of Israel’s political system, culture, and society; and developing American universities’ appreciation of Israel as a subject worthy of serious attention. AICE's goals also include highlighting areas where Israel might contribute to the betterment of America, and publishing studies to identify specific programs and approaches that can benefit [[Americans]]. According to its mission statement, AICE aims to provide a vehicle for research, study and discussion between the peoples and governments of the United States and Israel; to facilitate of partnership between both nations; organize and publish joint activities that benefit the two; and provide resources, material, and more to promote scholarship in the field of Israel studies.{{cite web|title=About AICE|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/about-aice|work=JVL|accessdate=27 October 2013}} Over the years, AICE's material has been cited by news and media outlets such as [[CNN]],{{cite news|title=Rabbi, wife 'spread Jewish pride' in Mumbai|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/11/28/india.jewish.center.attack/index.html?iref=mpstoryview|accessdate=21 December 2013|newspaper=CNN - Asia}} [[Yahoo news]],{{cite news|last=Vasilogambros|first=Matt|title=Could John Kerry Broker a Mideast Peace Deal? Probably Not|url=https://news.yahoo.com/could-john-kerry-broker-mideast-peace-deal-probably-153615506--politics.html|newspaper=Yahoo|accessdate=21 December 2013|date=January 28, 2013}} [[Haaretz]],{{cite news|last=Neistat|first=Aimee|title=Israeli photo exhibition opens a window into the lives of Georgian Jews|url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/israeli-photo-exhibition-opens-a-window-into-the-lives-of-georgian-jews-1.420044|accessdate=21 December 2013|newspaper=Haaretz|date=March 22, 2012}} [[USA Today]]{{cite web | title=Jerusalem timeline: a city rich with history, steeped in change | website=USA TODAY | date=June 8, 2015 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/06/08/jerusalem-timeline-history-supreme-court/28711565/ | access-date=December 31, 2017}} and others. A member of the [[Israel on Campus Coalition]],{{cite web|title=Tenured or Tenduous: Defining the Role of Faculty in Supporting Israel on Campus|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/pub/Tenured_or_Tenuous.pdf|work=JVL|accessdate=5 February 2014}} AICE is independently supported by donations from various foundations and individuals.{{cite web|last=Koren|first=Annette|title=Advancing Israel Studies in U.S. Universities 2005-2008: The American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|url=http://www.bjpa.org/Publications/downloadFile.cfm?FileID=17816|work=[[Brandeis University]]|publisher=[[Berman Jewish Policy Archive @ NYU Wagner]]|date=September 2008|accessdate=20 March 2014}} [[Shlomo Avineri]], [[Gerald Steinberg]], Joshua Teitelbaum,{{cite web|title=AICE Conference Participant Bios 2013-2014 |url=http://bomah.org/media/ConferenceBios2013-2014.pdf |accessdate=27 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029200438/http://bomah.org/media/ConferenceBios2013-2014.pdf |archivedate=29 October 2013 }} [[Bernice Manocherian]]{{cite web|title=AICE - board of directors|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/board.html|accessdate=10 May 2014}} are among the organization's board members. ==Activities== AICE maintains a database that containing joint U.S.-Israel activities. The database includes recipients of grants from the [[Binational Science Foundation]] (BSF), the Binational Agricultural Research and Development Foundation (BARD) and the Binational Industrial Research and Development Foundation (BIRD). Its Economic Partnership Databank contains information on more than 10,000 U.S. companies doing business in or with Israel. To address the critical need to develop new scholars and place established Israel scholars on campus, AICE has created the Israel Scholar Development Fund (ISDF). Some of their other major projects include bringing Israeli professors to teach Israel-related courses on U.S campuses, supporting visiting Israeli scholars teaching in the US. ===Visiting Israeli Professors (VIPs)=== AICE fellowship program, "Schusterman Visiting Israeli Professors",{{cite web|title=Israel |url=http://www.schusterman.org/interests/israel/schusterman-visiting-israel-professors |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140510224508/http://www.schusterman.org/interests/israel/schusterman-visiting-israel-professors |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 May 2014 |work=Charles & Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation |accessdate=10 May 2014 }} brings Israeli academics to American campuses{{cite web | title=The year BDS became the number one concern for American Jews | website=haaretz.com | date=December 27, 2014 | url=https://www.haaretz.com/jewish/features/.premium-1.633972 | access-date=December 31, 2017}} in order to ensure that expertise in the field will continue to be available from Israel while expanding within the United States. Visiting Israeli professors come from the Israeli universities [[Hebrew University]], [[University of Haifa]], [[Tel Aviv University]], [[Ben Gurion University]], and [[Bar Ilan University]]. In 2008, AICE financially assisted 29 Israelis (26 professors and three postdoctoral fellows) offering 70 courses in 27 universities throughout the United States and a further 11 graduate fellows and two postdoctoral research fellows. In the 2014-15 academic year, AICE reportedly selected 20 VIPs.https://israbib.wordpress.com/2012/07/10/fvipus1314/ ===Other Projects=== AICE's initiatives also include: *[http://www.iranintelligence.com/ Intelligence on Iran]: A free, online resource providing in-depth expert analysis, extensive primary source material, and a news media archive covering aspects and issues related to the [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iranian nuclear program]]".{{cite web|title=iranintelligence - About|url=http://www.iranintelligence.com/aboutus|accessdate=5 February 2014}} *The Dream Team Initiative and Campus Intelligence Project: An initiative created with the purpose of countering the boycott Israel movement and other attacks against Israel, and investigating the subject. *[http://www.stopbds.com/ "Stop BDS project]: Launched in 2010, it is an online resource for students on campus and others who wish to fight the anti-Israel [[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions]] (BDS) movement in their communities.{{cite web|title=STOPBDS.COM and BDS Cookbook Developed to Fight Boycotts on Campuses |url=http://www.jnf.org/caravan-for-democracy/news/bdscookbook.html |work=[[Jewish National Fund]] |accessdate=5 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222034225/http://www.jnf.org/caravan-for-democracy/news/bdscookbook.html |archivedate=22 February 2014 }} *[http://joesisrael.com/about/ Joe’s Israel]: A social media campaign launched on the web, which provides a platform to empower college students in North America for a dialogue on Israel.{{cite web|last=[[Andre Oboler]]|title=Joe’s Israel: Empowerment through Social Media|url=http://blogs.jpost.com/content/joe%E2%80%99s-israel-empowerment-through-social-media|publisher=[[Jpost]]|date=September 3, 2012|accessdate=5 February 2014}} *[http://www.israelcalendar.org/ "The Israel Calendar"]: A web-based calendar, was designed to provide the pro-Israel community a monthly focus to structure Israel activism on college campuses and in Jewish communities.{{cite web|title=The Israel Calendar - About|url=http://www.israelcalendar.org/index.php?indpge=8&ve=-1&postId=4|accessdate=5 February 2014}} ===Publications=== Books published by the American–Israeli Cooperative Enterprise include:{{cite web|title=AICE - Publications|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/aice-publications|accessdate=5 February 2014}} *{{cite book|author=Mitchell Geoffrey Bard|title=Myths And Facts: A Guide to the Arab-Israeli Conflict|url=https://smile.amazon.com/Myths-Facts-Guide-Arab-Israeli-Conflict-ebook/dp/B01MR12ZXU/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1524061157&sr=8-1&keywords=myths+and+facts|year=2017|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|isbn=1537152726}} *{{cite book|author1=Mitchell Geoffrey Bard|author2=Jeff Dawson|author3=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|title=Israel and the Campus: The Real Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iQJHkgEACAAJ|year=2012|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise}}* *{{cite book|author1=Mitchell Geoffrey Bard|author2=Israel on Campus Coalition|author3=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise|title=Tenured Or Tenuous: Defining the Role of Faculty in Supporting Israel on Campus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NJIbMwEACAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Israel on Campus Coalition}} *{{cite book|author=Irvin M. Asher|title=Breakthrough Dividend: Israeli Innovations in Biotechnology that Could Benefit Americans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4i66GwAACAAJ|year=1995|publisher=American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise}} ==External links== *[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/ Official Website] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Organized Jewish Life in the United States|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise}} [[Category:Jewish organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Jewish studies research institutes]] [[Category:Jewish educational organizations]] [[Category:Charities based in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:1993 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Israel–United States relations]] [[Category:Jewish organizations]] [[Category:Research institutes in the United States]]

{{other uses|Arsinoe (disambiguation)}} [[File:Arsinoe II.jpg|thumb|350px|Coin of Arsinoe II struck under the rule of her husband-brother [[Ptolemy II Philadelphus]].]]
[[Image:ArsinoeII.jpg|thumb|Arsinoe II]]
[[Image:Oktadrachmon Ptolemaios II Arsinoe II.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A gold coin shows paired, profiled busts of a plump man and woman. The man is in front and wears a diadem and drapery. It is inscribed "ΑΔΕΛΦΩΝ".|Head of Ptolemy II Philadelphus with Arsinoe II behind. The Greek inscription ''ΑΔΕΛΦΩΝ'' means "[coin] of the siblings".]]
'''Arsinoë II''' ({{lang-grc-koi|Ἀρσινόη}}, 316 BC – unknown date between July 270 and 260 BC) was a [[Ptolemaic dynasty|Ptolemaic queen]] and co-regent of the [[Ptolemaic Kingdom]] of [[ancient Egypt]].
Arsinoe was queen of [[Thrace]], [[Anatolia]] and [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]] by marriage to King [[Lysimachus]] ({{lang-grc-koi|Λυσίμαχος}}) and co-ruler of the [[Ptolemaic Kingdom]] with her brother-husband, [[Pharaoh]] [[Ptolemy II Philadelphus]] ({{lang|grc|Πτολεμαῖος Φιλάδελφος}} "Ptolemy the Sibling-Loving"). Arsinoe was given the unprecedented Egyptian title "King of [[Upper and Lower Egypt]]", marking her as a full pharaoh.<ref>{{cite book|last=Donnelly Carney|first=Elizabeth |authorlink=Elizabeth Donnelly Carney|title=Arsinoe of Egypt and Macedon: A Royal Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bmzRCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115|year=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-971101-7|page=115}}</ref>
==Life==
===Early life=== Arsinoë was the first daughter of Pharaoh [[Ptolemy I Soter]] (Greek: Πτολεμαίος Σωτήρ, "Ptolemy the Savior"), founder of the Hellenistic state of Egypt, and his second wife [[Berenice I of Egypt]].<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Did female Egyptian pharaoh rule before Cleopatra? |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40472692/ns/technology_and_science-science/ |quote= |work=[[MSNBC]] |date=December 2, 2010 |accessdate=2010-12-05 }}</ref>
She was born in [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]], but was raised in the new city of [[Alexandria]], where her father moved his capital early on.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney">Elizabeth Donnelly Carney (2013). Arsinoe of Egypt and Macedon: A Royal Life. New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-536551-1}}.</ref> Nothing is known of her childhood or education, but judging from her later life as patron of scholars and noted for her learning, she is estimated to have been given a high education.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/> Her brothers where tutored by intellectuals hired by their fathers, and it is regarded likely that she attended these lessons as well: she corresponded with the intellectual [[Strato of Lampsacus]] later in life, and he may have previously been her tutor.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/>
===Queen of Lysimachus=== At about age 15, Arsinoë married King Lysimachus (who was then around 60 years old),<ref>{{cite book|last=Carney|first=Elizabeth Donnelly|authorlink=Elizabeth Donnelly Carney|title=Arsinoe of Egypt and Macedon: A Royal Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hYGL8RM_jb0C&pg=PA31|year=2013|publisher=OUP USA|isbn=978-0-19-536551-1|page=31}}</ref> with whom she had three sons: [[Ptolemy Epigonos]],<ref>Billows, ''Kings and colonists: aspects of Macedonian imperialism'', p.110</ref><ref>Bengtson, ''Griechische Geschichte von den Anfängen bis in die römische Kaiserzeit'', p.569</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tyndalehouse.com/egypt/ptolemies/nios_i.htm|title=Ptolemy "the Son"|website=www.tyndalehouse.com|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> [[Lysimachus (son of Lysimachus)|Lysimachus]],<ref>Bengtson, ''Griechische Geschichte von den Anfängen bis in die römische Kaiserzeit'', p.569</ref> and [[Philip (son of Lysimachus)|Philip]].<ref>Bengtson, ''Griechische Geschichte von den Anfängen bis in die römische Kaiserzeit'', p.569</ref>
In order to position her sons for the throne, she had Lysimachus' first son, [[Agathocles (son of Lysimachus)|Agathocles]], poisoned on account of treason.
Arsinoe reportedly paid for a rotunda in the [[Samothrace temple complex]], where she was likely an initiate.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/>
===Queen of Ptolemy Keraunos=== After Lysimachus' death in battle in 281 BC, she fled to [[Cassandreia]] ({{lang|grc|Κασσάνδρεια}}) and married her paternal half-brother [[Ptolemy Keraunos]], one of the sons of Ptolemy I Soter from his previous wife, [[Eurydice of Egypt]]. The marriage was for political reasons as they both claimed the throne of Macedonia and Thrace (by the time of his death Lysimachus was ruler of both regions, and his power extended to southern Greece and [[Anatolia]]). Their relationship was never good.
As Ptolemy Keraunos was becoming more powerful, she decided it was time to stop him and conspired against him with her sons. This action caused Ptolemy Keraunus to kill two of her sons, Lysimachus and Philip, while the eldest, Ptolemy, was able to escape and to flee north, to the kingdom of the Dardanians.
She herself sought refuge in the Samothrace temple complex, which she had benefited during her tenure as queen.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/> She eventually left from Samothrace for Alexandria, Egypt, to seek protection from her brother, [[Ptolemy II Philadelphus]].
It is not known which year she left for Egypt. She may have left so early as 280, directly after the murder of the younger sons, or as late as 276, when the claim of her eldest son to the Macedonian throne had clearly failed after the succession of [[Antigonus II Gonatas]].<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/>
[[File:Cameo gonzaga.jpg|thumb|right|"[[Gonzaga Cameo]]", [[Hermitage Museum]]]]
===Queen of Egypt===
In Egypt, she is believed to have instigated the accusation and exile of her brother Ptolemy II's first wife, [[Arsinoe I]]. Whether this was actually true is unknown: it is not known which year she arrived in Egypt, and her sister-in-law may already have been exiled at that point, or her divorce may have taken place without her involvement.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/>
Whatever the case, after the divorce of Ptolemy, Arsinoe II then married her brother. As a result, both were given the epithet "Philadelphoi" ({{lang-grc-koi|Φιλάδελφοι}} "Sibling-loving (plural)") by the presumably-scandalized Greeks. The closer circumstances and reasons behind the marriage is not known.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/>
Her role as queen was unprecedented in the dynasty at the time and became a role model for later Ptolemaic queens: she acted alongside her brother in ritual and public display, became a religious and literal patron and was included in the Egyptian and Greek cults created by him for them.<ref name="Elizabeth Donnelly Carney"/> Sharing in all of her brother's titles, she apparently was quite influential, having towns dedicated to her, her own cult (as was Egyptian custom), appearing on coinage and contributing to foreign policy, including Ptolemy II's victory in the [[Syrian Wars#First Syrian War .28274-271 BC.29|First Syrian War]] between Egypt and the [[Seleucid Empire]].
According to [[Posidippus]], she won three [[chariot race]]s at the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]], probably in 272 BC.<ref>Posidippus, P. Mil. Vogl. VIII 309, AB 78.</ref><ref>Donnelly Carney, Arsinoe of Egypt and Macedon: A Royal Life, pag. 142.</ref>
==Legacy== After her death, Ptolemy II continued to refer to her on official documents, as well as supporting her coinage and cult. In establishing her worship as a goddess he justified his own cult.
==See also== *[[Arsinoitherium]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

Mil. Vogl. VIII 309}}

Borza (eds), ''Philip II, Alexander the Great and the Macedonian Heritage'' (Washington, 1982), 197-212 * P. McKechnie and P. Guillaume (eds) ''Ptolemy II Philadelphus and his World''. Leiden, 2008. * M. Nilsson, ''The Crown of Arsinoë II: The Creation of an Image of Authority''. Oxford, 2012. * D. L. Selden, Daniel L. "Alibis". ''Classical Antiquity'' '''17''' (2), October 1998.
==External links== {{commons category|Arsinoe II}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070311041018/http://data.numismatics.org/cgi-bin/showobj?accnum=1974.26.801 Coin with her portrait] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071201083945/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9009647 Encyclopædia Britannica] *[http://virtualreligion.net/iho/arsinoe_2.html Arsinoe II] entry in historical sourcebook by Mahlon H. Smith

revision.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox school |name = Athena School |image = |alt = |caption = |motto = Persistence - Integrity - Understanding |motto_translation = |city = [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]] |state = [[New South Wales]] |country = [[Australia]] |coordinates = {{coord|33|53|44.04|S|151|10|28.10|E|display=inline,title|type:edu}} |schooltype = [[Private School|Private]] [[Comprehensive School|Comprehensive]] [[Coeducational]] School |religious_affiliation = |established = |principal = |viceprincipal = |viceprincipal_label = |asst principal = |assistant_principals = |teaching_staff = |grades = K-10 |enrolment = |campus type = |colours = |website = {{url|http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/}} }} The '''Athena School''' is an independent, co-educational school for Preschool to Year 10 students located in [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]], an [[Inner West (Sydney)|inner western suburb]] of [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales, Australia]]. The teaching approaches of the school are based on the works of [[L. Ron Hubbard]]. The school is registered by the [[Board of Studies, Teaching and Educational Standards]] and is a member of the NSW Association of Independent Schools. The school uses [[Study Tech]].[http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/service.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912131933/http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/service.htm |date=12 September 2007 }} == Athena School and The Church of Scientology == The school is affiliated with the [[Church of Scientology]]{{Cite news|publication-date=2000-11-10 |year=2000 |title=Senate |periodical=Official Hansard |series=Parliamentary Debates |publication-place=Canberra |publisher=Commonwealth of Australia |volume=39 |issue=16 |page=19 |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Hansard/senate/dailys/ds101100.pdf |accessdate=2007-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831093317/http://www.aph.gov.au/hansard/senate/dailys/ds101100.pdf |archivedate=31 August 2007 |df=dmy }}{{cite news| first = Kelly | last = Burke| title = Scientology class suits shy Hindu| url = http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/06/23/1056220542333.html| work = Religion in Schools| publisher = The Sydney Morning Herald| date = 2003-06-24| accessdate = 2007-10-25}} with teachings based on [[L. Ron Hubbard|L. Ron Hubbard's]] philosophy of education, centered on overcoming the fundamental barriers that prevent one from fully comprehending one’s studies.{{cite web |url=http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/information/study-technology/the-barriers-to-study |title=The Barriers to Study |publisher=Athena.nsw.edu.au |date=2010-08-08 |accessdate=2013-12-01 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131201122827/http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/information/study-technology/the-barriers-to-study |archive-date=1 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Per their website, the school states, "The Athena School is licensed under Applied Scholastics International to use the educational philosophy of author and humanitarian L. Ron Hubbard. As he is also the founder of Scientology, there can be some assumption that The Athena School is a religious school when we are not. The Athena School does not promote any one religion. Our students learn tolerance and respect in accordance with Article 18 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights."{{cite web|url=http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/is-the-athena-school-a-scientology-school/ |title=Is The Athena School a Scientology School? |publisher=Athena.nsw.edu.au |date=2013-12-24 |accessdate=2013-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225061353/http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/is-the-athena-school-a-scientology-school/ |archivedate=25 December 2013 |df=dmy }} Since 2007, all teachers are registered with the Board of Studies, Teaching and Educational Standards.{{cite web|url=http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au |title=Welcome to The Athena School | Private School in Sydney | Primary School | High School | Independent School |publisher=Athena.nsw.edu.au |date=2010-08-08 |accessdate=2013-06-01}} The Athena School follows the guidelines set out by the [[NSW Board of Studies]] in its curriculum. In March 2010 the [[Greens New South Wales]] party lodged an official complaint about the school to the [[Australian Competition and Consumer Commission]] due to an advertising leaflet which fails to reveal the school's link to Scientology. The Principal of the school said the Applied Scholastics study method did not teach the Scientology religion, "We follow the Board of Studies curriculum. We use the study method of L. Ron Hubbard. It is a method of study, it is not teaching Scientology."{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/03/09/2840274.htm |title=Greens refer Scientology school to consumer watchdog - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2013-06-01}} == Green School program with Street Coolers == In 2015 the school started a "green school" program with Street Coolers, a community-focused organisation with a mission to cool our urban areas. This involved the school utilising several machines capable of creating several kilograms of compost per day, a reverse-vending machine open to the public, which allows individuals to recycle plastic bottles and aluminium cans for coupons, as well as energy and weather monitoring to assess power usage and how the weather affects this.{{Cite web|title = Paving The Way For Sustainable Schools {{!}} The Athena School|url = http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/3332/the-athena-school-is-paving-the-way-for-sustainable-schools/|website = The Athena School|accessdate = 2015-12-16|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151222122938/http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/3332/the-athena-school-is-paving-the-way-for-sustainable-schools/|archive-date = 22 December 2015|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} == See also == *[[Scientology in Australia]] * [[List of non-government schools in New South Wales]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite news | first=Brian | last=Seymour | coauthors= | authorlink= | title=Scientology lesson | date=9 December 2009 | publisher=Yahoo! Australia & NZ Pty Limited | url=http://au.todaytonight.yahoo.com/article/6569078/money/scientology-lesson | work=Today Tonight | pages= | accessdate=2009-12-09 | language= | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213020835/http://au.todaytonight.yahoo.com/article/6569078/money/scientology-lesson | archive-date=13 December 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} ==External links== * [http://www.athena.nsw.edu.au/ Athena School website] [[Category:Private high schools in Sydney]] [[Category:Private primary schools in Sydney]] [[Category:School buildings completed in 1987]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1987]] [[Category:Scientology-related schools]] [[Category:1987 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Newtown, New South Wales]] {{NewSouthWales-school-stub}} {{Scientology-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
Resolved a disputed usage of "around". Cheers.
revision.text:
{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The [[Bahá'í Faith]] has had challenges to its leadership, usually at the death of the head of the religion.<ref name="maceoin2">{{cite encyclopedia |title=Bahai and Babi Schisms |encyclopedia=Iranica |publisher= |location= |id= |url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bahaism-iii |first=Dennis |last=MacEoin |quote=The history of Bahaism as a distinct movement is punctuated by divisions of varying severity, usually occurring as responses to the death of one of the religion’s leaders.}}</ref><ref name="Barrett p. 247">{{Harvnb|Barrett|2001|pp=247–248}}</ref> The vast majority of Bahá'ís have followed a line of authority from [[Bahá'u'lláh]] to [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] to [[Shoghi Effendi]] to the [[Custodians]] to the [[Universal House of Justice]].<ref name="Momen 64">{{Harvnb|Momen|Smith|1989|p=64}}</ref><ref name="ency_cb">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=115–116}}</ref> [[Sect]]s diverging from this line of leadership have failed to attract a sizeable following.<ref name="maceoin">{{cite encyclopedia |title=Bahai and Babi Schisms |encyclopedia=Iranica |publisher= |location= |id= |url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bahaism-iii |first=Dennis |last=MacEoin |quote=Other small groups have broken away from the main body from time to time, but none of these has attracted a sizeable following.}}</ref> In this sense, there is only one ''major'' branch of the Bahá'í Faith,<ref name = "adherents.com">[http://www.adherents.com/adh_branches.html#Baha'ism Major Branches of Religions Ranked by Number of Adherents], Adherents.com</ref> represented by at least 5 million adherents, whereas the groups that have broken away have either become extinct with time, or have remained very small in number, representing far less than 0.1% of all Bahá'ís.<ref name="Barrett p. 247"/><ref name="maceoin"/><ref name=smith116/> Globally the Bahá'í community has maintained its unity.<ref name=smith116>{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=116}} Quote from source: "Some attempts were made during the 1950s and 1960s to bring together the disparate groups of Covenant-breakers, but these had little effect. Globally, the Bahá'í community has maintained its unity."</ref>
[[Bahá'í literature|Bahá'í scriptures]] define a [[Covenant of Bahá'u'lláh#Lesser Covenant|Lesser Covenant]] regarding succession which is intended to keep the Bahá'ís unified.<ref name = "Momen 2003 D">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§D}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref> Claimants challenging the widely accepted successions of leadership are shunned by the majority group as [[Covenant breaker|Covenant-Breakers]].<ref name=smith116/>
A separate entry discusses the [[Bahá'í/Bábí split]].
==`Abdu'l-Bahá's ministry== {{anchor|abdulbaha-ministry}} Bahá'u'lláh remained in the Akka-Haifa area under house arrest until his death in 1892. According to the terms of [[Tablets of Bahá'u'lláh#Kitáb-i-`Ahd (Book of the Covenant)|his will]], his eldest son [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] was named the centre of authority; [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí]], the eldest son from Bahá'u'lláh's second wife, was assigned a secondary position.<ref>Bahá'u'lláh, ''Tablets of Bahá'u'lláh'', [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/TB/tb-16.html#pg221 p. 221]</ref>
Pursuant to his role as Centre of the Covenant, `Abdu'l-Bahá became the head of the Bahá'í community. Soon Muhammad `Ali complained that `Abdu'l-Bahá was not sharing authority and he started working against his elder brother.<ref name="ency_ali">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=252}}</ref> Most members of the families of Bahá'u'lláh's second and third wives supported Muhammad `Alí; however, there were very few outside of Haifa who followed him.<ref name="ency_ali"/>
Muhammad `Alí's machinations with the Ottoman authorities resulted in `Abdu'l-Bahá's re-arrest and confinement in [[Acre, Israel|Acre]].<ref>{{harvnb|Smith|2008|p=44}}</ref> They also caused the appointment of two official commissions of inquiry, which almost led to further exile and incarceration of `Abdu'l-Baha to North Africa. In the aftermath of the Young Turk revolution, Ottoman prisoners were freed thus ending the danger to `Abdu'l-Baha.<ref>{{harvnb|Smith2008|pg=43-44}}</ref> Meanwhile, [[Ibrahim George Kheiralla]], a Syrian Christian, converted to the Bahá'í Faith, emigrated to the United States and founded the first American Bahá'í community.<ref name="Smith:Kheiralla">{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Peter |authorlink=Peter Smith (historian) |year=1999 |title=A Concise Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location=Oxford, UK |page=218 |isbn=1-85168-184-1}}</ref> Initially, he was loyal to 'Abdu'l-Bahá. With time Kheiralla began teaching that `Abdu'l-Baha was the return of Christ, and this was becoming the widespread understanding among the Bahá'ís in the United States, despite `Abdu'l-Baha's efforts to correct the mistake.<ref name="Smith:Kheiralla"/><ref>{{Cite book |last=Smith |first=Peter |authorlink=Peter Smith (historian) |title=The Baha'i Faith in the West |publisher=Kalimat Press |year=2004 |location= |pages=4, 7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC&lpg=PP13&pg=PA4#v=onepage&q |isbn=978-1-890688-11-0}}</ref> Later on, Kheiralla switched sides in the conflict between Bahá'u'lláh's sons and supported Mirza Muhammad Ali. He formed the Society of Behaists, a religious denomination promoting Unitarian Bahaism in the U.S., which was later led by [[Shua Ullah Behai]], son of Mirza Muhammad Ali, after he emigrated to the United States in June 1904 at the behest of his father.<ref>{{Cite journal | editor-last = Cole | editor-first = Juan R.I. | editor2-last = Quinn | editor2-first = Sholeh | editor3-last = Smith | editor3-first = Peter | editor4-last = Walbridge | editor4-first = John |title=Behai Quarterly |journal=Documents on the Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Movements |volume=08 |issue=2 |publisher=h-net.msu.edu |date=July 2004 |url=http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/docs/vol8/bq.htm |accessdate=2010-04-17}}</ref> Muhammad `Alí's supporters either called themselves Behaists <ref name="Behai Quarterly">Shu'a'ullah, [http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/docs/vol8/bq.htm Behai Quarterly] [http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/docs/vol8/42BQ03.gif Volume 4] [http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/docs/vol8/42BQ23.gif Page 23]</ref> or "Unitarian Bahá'ís".<ref>Browne, [http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/diglib/books/A-E/B/browne/material/msbrtoc.htm p. 82]. The reference appears to be to the [[Unitarianism|unitarian]] theology of one god, rather than any identification with the [[American Unitarian Association]].</ref> From 1934 to 1937, Behai published Behai Quarterly a Unitarian Bahai magazine written in English and featuring the writings of Muhammad Ali and various other Unitarian Bahais.<ref name="WarburgStudies">{{Cite book |last=Warburg |first=Margit |title=Bahá'í: Studies in Contemporary Religion |publisher=Signature Books |date= |page=64 |url=http://signaturebooks.com/?p=1164 |isbn=1-56085-169-4 |access-date=2010-04-18 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130202111901/http://signaturebooks.com/?p=1164 |archive-date=2013-02-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá's response to determined opposition during his tenure was patterned on Bahá'u'lláh's<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.b">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§G.2.b}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref> example and evolved across three stages. Initially, like Bahá'u'lláh,<ref name="Momen 2003 G.2.b"/> he made no public statements but communicated with his brother Muhammad `Alí and his associates directly, or through intermediaries, in seeking reconciliation. When it became clear that reconciliation was not possible, and fearing damage to the community, 'Abdu'l-Bahá wrote to the Bahá'ís explaining the situation, identifying the individuals concerned and instructing the believers to sever all ties with those involved. Finally, he sent representatives to those areas most affected by the problem.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.c">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§G.2.c}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref>
The function of these representatives was to explain matters to the Bahá'ís and to encourage them to persevere in cutting all contact. Often these chosen individuals would have `Abdu'l-Bahá's authority to open up communications with those involved to try to persuade them to return. In Iran, such envoys were principally the four [[Hands of the Cause#Appointed by Bahá'u'lláh|Hands of the Cause]] appointed by Bahá'u'lláh.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.c"/>
===Aftermath=== {{anchor|Aftermath}} When `Abdu'l-Bahá died, [[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá|his Will and Testament]] explained in some detail how Muhammad `Alí had been unfaithful to the Covenant, identifying him as a [[Covenant-breaker]] and appointing [[Shoghi Effendi]] as leader of the Faith with the title of [[Guardian (Bahá'í Faith)|Guardian]]. Bahá'í authors such as Hasan Balyuzi and Adib Taherzadeh set about refuting the claims of Muhammad `Alí. This represented what is often described as the most testing time for the [[Bahá'í Faith]].<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.c"/> The Behaists rejected the authority of the [[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá]], claiming loyalty to the leadership succession as they inferred it from Baha'u'llah's [[Tablets of Bahá'u'lláh#Kitáb-i-`Ahd (Book of the Covenant)|Kitab-i-Ahd]].<ref name="Behai Quarterly"/>
This schism had very little effect. In the `Akká area, the followers of Muhammad `Alí represented six families at most, they had no common religious activities,<ref name="WarburgStudies"/> and were almost wholly assimilated into Muslim society.<ref name="maceoin3">{{cite encyclopedia |title=Bahai and Babi Schisms |encyclopedia=Iranica |publisher= |location= |id= |url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bahaism-iii |first=Dennis |last=MacEoin |quote=In Palestine, the followers of Moḥammad-ʿAlī continued as a small group of families opposed to the Bahai leadership in Haifa; they have now been almost wholly re-assimilated into Muslim society.}}</ref> A modern academic observer has reported an attempt to revive the claims of Muhammad Ali in order to lend legitimacy to a newly established sect avowing loyalty to Bahá'u'lláh but rejecting the authority that Bahá'u'lláh gave to 'Abdu’l-Bahá and to the Universal House of Justice.<ref>{{Cite web |last=McGlinn |first=Sen |title=A Muhammad Ali revival? |work= |date=March 27, 2010 |url=http://senmcglinn.wordpress.com/2010/03/27/muhammad-ali/ |accessdate=2010-04-17}}</ref> In addition, Nigar Bahai Amsalem, the great-granddaughter of Bahá'u'lláh and granddaughter of both Mirza Muhammad Ali and Bahá'u'lláh's youngest son [[Mirza Badi'u'llah Effendí|Badi'u'llah]], was interviewed<ref name="thetruth">{{Cite web |last=Masumian |first=Abid |last2=Momen |first2=Moojan |title=The Truth about Baha'u'llah's Great-Granddaughter, Nigar Bahai Amsalem |publisher=? |date=n.d. |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/17497747/Bahaullahs-Great-Grand-Daughter-Nigar-Bahai-Amsalem |accessdate=2010-04-17}}</ref> in the 2006 Israeli [[mockumentary]] film <ref>{{Cite web |last=Schory |first=Noemi |title=Producer's Statement |work=Bahais in My Backyard, A Belfilms Production |publisher=firsthandfilms.com |date=2010-04-17 |url=http://www.firsthandfilms.com/index.php?film=1000184 |accessdate=2010-04-17}}</ref>''Baha'is In My Backyard''. It mentions that she has built a shrine at the tomb of Mirza Muhammad Ali and opposes the Universal House of Justice. She withheld information on the extent of her opposition during her interview for the film.<ref name="thetruth"/>
==Shoghi Effendi as Guardian== {{anchor|Shoghi}}
===Appointment=== [[File:Shoghi Effendi2.jpg|thumb|200px|Shoghi Effendi at the time of becoming Guardian in 1921. Taken in Haifa.]] At 24, [[Shoghi Effendi]] was particularly young when he assumed leadership of the religion in 1921, as provided for by `Abdu'l-Bahá in his Will and Testament. He had received a Western education at the [[American University of Beirut|Syrian Protestant College]] and later at [[Balliol College]], [[Oxford]].
At this time Muhammad-`Alí revived his claim to leadership of the Bahá'í community.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.d.iv"/> He seized the keys of the Tomb of Bahá'u'lláh at the [[mansion of Bahjí]], expelled its keeper, and demanded that he be recognized by the authorities as the legal custodian of that property. However, the Palestine authorities, after having conducted some investigations, instructed the British officer in `Akká to deliver the keys into the hands of the keeper loyal to Shoghi Effendi.<ref>See {{Harvnb|Effendi|1944|p=355}} [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/GPB/gpb-24.html#pg355]</ref>
===American disputes=== After the death of `Abdu'l-Bahá, [[Ruth White (Bahá'í author)|Ruth White]] questioned the Will's authenticity as early as 1926,<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.d.i">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§G.2.d.i}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref> and openly opposed Shoghi Effendi's Guardianship, publishing several books on the subject. She wrote a letter to the United States Postmaster General and asked him, among other things, to prohibit the National Spiritual Assembly from "using the United States Mails to spread the falsehood that Shoghi Effendi is the successor of `Abdu'l-Bahá and the Guardian of the Cause." She also wrote a letter to the High Commissioner for Palestine; both of these letters were ignored.
Another division occurred primarily within the American Bahá'í community, which increasingly consisted of non-Persians with an interest in alternative spiritual pursuits. Many had been strongly attracted to the personality of `Abdu'l-Bahá and the spiritual teachings of the Bahá'í Faith. Some regarded it as an ecumenical society to which all persons of goodwill—regardless of religion—might join. When Shoghi Effendi made clear his position that the Bahá'í Faith was an independent religion with its own distinct administration through local and national spiritual assemblies, a few felt that he had overstepped the bounds of his authority. Most prominent among them was a New York group including [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]], [[Lewis Stuyvesant Chanler|Lewis]] and [[Julia Lynch Olin|Julia Chanler]], who founded the "New History Society", and its youth section, the [[Caravan of East and West]].<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.d.ii">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§G.2.d.ii}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref><ref>Mirza Ahmad Sohrab, ''The Bahá'í Cause'' [http://bahai-library.com/sohrab_ferm pp. 309-14]</ref> Sohrab and the Chanlers refused to be overseen by the New York Spiritual Assembly, and were expelled by Shoghi Effendi as [[Covenant-breaker]]s.<ref name="ency_sohrab"/> They argued that the expulsion was meaningless because they believed the faith could not be institutionalized. The New History Society published several works by Sohrab and Chanler and others. Sohrab accepted the legitimacy of Shoghi Effendi as Guardian, but was critical of the manner of his leadership and the methods of organizing the Bahá'í administration.<ref name="ency_sohrab">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=325}}</ref> The New History Society attracted fewer than a dozen Bahá'ís, however its membership swelled to several thousand for a time. The New History Society was active until 1959 and is now defunct.<ref>{{cite book |title=Baha'is in the West |volume=14 | editor-first = Peter |editor-last= Smith |year=2004 |publisher=Kalimat Press |first=Peter |last=Smith |authorlink=Peter Smith (historian) |page=15}}</ref> The Caravan House, aka Caravan Institute, later disassociated itself from the Bahá'í Faith, and remained as an unrelated non-profit educational organization.<ref>Moojan Momen 2003, § G.2.d.ii [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant] See also New York Tax Exempt and NonProfit Organizations [http://www.taxexemptworld.com/organizations/new_york_ny_10021.asp]</ref>
All of the divisions of this period were short-lived and restricted in their influence.<ref name="maceoin2"/>
===Family members expelled=== {{Main article|Covenant-breaker}} In 1932 Shoghi Effendi's great aunt, [[Bahiyyih Khanum]], died. She was highly respected and had instructed all to follow Shoghi Effendi through several telegrams she had sent around the world announcing the basics of the provisions of `Abdu'l-Bahá's will and was witness to the actions relatives took in violation of provisions of the will.<ref name="JKhanProphetDaughter123">{{cite book |last=Khan |first=Janet A. |year=2005 |title=Prophet's Daughter: The Life and Legacy of Bahíyyih Khánum, Outstanding Heroine Of The Bahá'í Faith |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=1-931847-14-2 |pages=123–4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-8W-2DjcShcC&lpg=PR3&pg=PA123#v=onepage&q}}</ref> Bahíyyih Khánum had devoted much of her life towards protecting the accepted leadership of the Bahá'í Faith and after Shoghi Effendi's appointment there was little internal opposition until after her death when nephews began to openly oppose Shoghi Effendi over Bahá'u'lláh's house in Baghdad.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.d.iv">{{cite web |first=Moojan |last=Momen |title=Covenant, The, and Covenant-breaker |url=http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking. |accessdate=2009-06-27}}</ref> Some family members disapproved of his marriage to a Westerner, [[Rúhíyyih Khanum|Mary Maxwell]] — daughter of one of the foremost disciples of `Abdu'l-Bahá — in 1937. They claimed that Shoghi Effendi introduced innovations beyond the Iranian roots of the Faith. This gradually resulted in his siblings and cousins disobeying his instructions and marrying into the families of [[Covenant-breaker]]s, many of whom were expelled as Covenant-breakers themselves. However, these disagreements within Shoghi Effendi's family resulted in no attempts to create a schism favouring an alternative leader. At the time of his death in 1957, he was the only remaining male member of the family of Bahá'u'lláh who had not been expelled. Even his own parents had openly fought against him.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.d.iv"/>
==The founding of the Universal House of Justice== {{anchor|HouseOfJustice}} Shoghi Effendi died in 1957 without explicitly appointing a successor Guardian.<ref name="ency_guardianship">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=169–170}}</ref> He had no children, and during his lifetime all remaining male descendants of Bahá'u'lláh had been [[excommunication|excommunicated]] as [[Covenant-breaker]]s.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> He left no will.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> Shoghi Effendi's appointed [[Hands of the Cause]] unanimously voted it was impossible to legitimately recognize and assent to a successor.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e">{{Harvnb|Momen|2003|loc=§G.2.e}} [http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant#5.%20Dealing%20with%20Covenant-breaking.]</ref> The Bahá'í community was in a situation not dealt with explicitly in the provisions of the Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> Furthermore, the [[Universal House of Justice]] had not yet been elected, which represented the only Bahá'í institution authorized to adjudicate on matters not covered by the religion's three central figures.<ref name="ency_hands">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=175–177}}</ref> To understand the transition following the death of Shoghi Effendi in 1957, an explanation of the roles of the Guardian, the Hands of the Cause, and the Universal House of Justice is useful.
===Guardianship=== [[File:Willandtestofabdulbaha.jpg|right|120px]] {{Main article|Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá}} Other than allusions in the writings of Bahá'u'lláh to the importance of the [[Aghsán]], the role of the Guardian was not mentioned until the reading of the Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá. Shoghi Effendi later expressed to his wife and others that he had no foreknowledge of the existence of the Institution of Guardianship, least of all that he was appointed as Guardian.<ref name="ency_will">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=356–357}}</ref>
`Abdu'l-Bahá warned the Bahá'ís to avoid the problems caused by his half-brother [[Mírzá Muhammad `Alí|Muhammad `Alí]].<ref name="ency_will"/> He stipulated the criteria and form for selecting future Guardians, which was to be clear and unambiguous.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> His will required that the Guardian appoint his successor "in his own life-time ... that differences may not arise after his [the Guardian's] passing."<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> The appointee was required to be either the first-born son of the Guardian, or one of the [[Aghsán]] (literally: Branches; male descendants of Bahá'u'lláh).<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> Finally, `Abdu'l-Bahá left a responsibility to [[Custodians|nine Hands of the Cause]], elected from all of the Hands, who "whether unanimously or by a majority vote, must give their assent to the choice of the one whom the Guardian of the Cause of God hath chosen as his successor."<ref name="ency_hands"/>
The will also vested authority in the Guardian's appointed assistants, known as the [[Hands of the Cause]], giving them the right to "cast out from the congregation of the people of Bahá" anyone they deem in opposition to the Guardian.<ref name="ency_cb"/>
===Relationship between the Guardianship and the Universal House of Justice=== The roles of the Guardianship and the Universal House of Justice are complementary, the former providing authoritative interpretation, and the latter providing flexibility and the authority to adjudicate on "questions that are obscure and matters that are not expressly recorded in the Book."<ref name="ency_guardianship"/><ref name="ency_house">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=346–350}}</ref> The authority of the two institutions was elucidated by `Abdu'l-Bahá in his will, saying that rebellion and disobedience towards either the Guardian or the Universal House of Justice, is rebellion and disobedience towards God.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/><ref name="ency_house"/> Shoghi Effendi went into further detail explaining this relationship in ''The World Order of Bahá'u'lláh'', indicating that the institutions are interdependent.<ref name="ency_house"/>
===Role of the Hands of the Cause=== {{anchor|RoleOfHands}} {{Main article|Hands of the Cause}} Shortly after Shoghi Effendi's death, the 27 then-living Hands of the Cause (Hands) deliberated over whether or not they could legitimately consent to any successor.<ref name="Momen 89">{{Harvnb|Momen|Smith|1989|p=89}}</ref> Only two members present could translate between English and Persian.{{sfn|Gallagher|Ashcraft|2006|p=201}} Following these events Time Magazine reported that there were debates about two possible candidates for Guardian.<ref>Time Magazine Dec. 9, 1957 [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,810155,00.html "In the Hands of the Hands"]</ref>
On November 25, 1957, the Hands signed a unanimous proclamation stating that he had died "without having appointed his successor"; that "it is now fallen upon us... to preserve the unity, the security and the development of the Bahá'í World Community and all its institutions"; and that they would elect from among themselves nine Hands who would "exercise ... all such functions, rights and powers in succession to the Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith... as are necessary to serve the interests of the Bahá'í World Faith, and this until such time as the Universal House of Justice... may otherwise determine." This body of nine Hands became known as the Hands of the Cause in the Holy Land, sometimes referred to as the [[Custodians]].<ref name="ency_custodians">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|p=117}}</ref>
That same day the Hands passed a unanimous resolution that clarified who would have authority over various executive areas.<ref name="ency_cb"/><ref>For their authority, the Custodians referred to the ''Will and Testament of `Abdul-Bahá'' which states that "the Hands of the Cause of God must elect from their own number nine persons that shall at all times be occupied in the important services in the work of the Guardian of the Cause of God.”{{Harv|Hatcher|Martin|1998|p=190}}{{Harv|`Abdu'l-Bahá|1901-08|p=12}} See: Rabbani, ''Ministry of the Custodians'', 1992, Letter of 28 May 1960, to all National Spiritual Assemblies (pp. 204-206), Letter of 5 July 1960, to all National Spiritual Assemblies (pp. 208-209), Letter of 7 July 1960, to all Hands of the Cause, Cable of 26 July 1960, to all National Spiritual Assemblies (p.223), and Letter of 15 October 1960, to all National Spiritual Assemblies (pp. 231-236)[http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians] In addition, the Guardian had written that the Hands had executive authority in carrying out his directives. {{Harv|Effendi|1982|pp=82–83}}[http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/LDG2/ldg2-95.html]</ref> Among these were: *"That the entire body of the Hands of the Cause, ... shall determine when and how the International Bahá'í Council shall pass through the successive stages outlined by Shoghi Effendi culminating in the election of the Universal House of Justice" *"That the authority to expel violators from the Faith shall be vested in the body of nine Hands [The Custodians.], acting on reports and recommendations submitted by Hands from their respective continents."
In their deliberations following Shoghi Effendi's passing they determined that they were not in a position to appoint a successor, only to ratify one, so they advised the Bahá'í community that the [[Universal House of Justice]] would consider the matter after it was established.<ref name="ency_hands"/>
In deciding when and how the [[International Bahá'í Council]] would develop into the Universal House of Justice, the Hands agreed to carry out Shoghi Effendi's plans for moving it from the appointed council, to an officially recognized Bahá'í Court, to a duly elected body, and then to the elected Universal House of Justice.<ref>See {{Harvnb|Rabbani|1992|p=37}} [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians#37] and {{Harvnb|Effendi|1971|pp-7-8}} [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-5.html]</ref> In November 1959, referring to the goal of becoming recognized as a [[Israeli judicial system#Non-Jewish religious courts|non-Jewish religious court]] in Israel, they said: "this goal, due to the strong trend towards the [[Secularism in Israel|secularization of Religious Courts]] in this part of the world, might not be achieved."<ref>See {{Harvnb|Rabbani|1992|p=169}} [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians#169]</ref><ref name="TCoB324">{{Harvnb|Taherzadeh|1992|p=324}}</ref> The recognition as a religious court was never achieved, and the International Bahá'í Council was reformed in 1961 as an elected body in preparation for forming the Universal House of Justice.<ref name="ency_council">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|p=200}}</ref> The Hands of the Cause made themselves ineligible for election to both the council and the Universal House of Justice.<ref name="ency_council"/>
Upon the election of the Universal House of Justice at the culmination of the [[Ten Year Crusade]] in 1963, the nine Hands acting as interim head of the religion closed their office.<ref name="ency_hands"/>
===Charles Mason Remey=== <!--other pages link directly to this section. Please avoid changes to its title -->
{{Main article|Mason Remey}} Charles Mason Remey was among the Hands who signed the unanimous proclamations in 1957, acknowledging that Shoghi Effendi had died without having appointed his successor.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/><ref name="ency_remey">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|p=292}}</ref> He was also among the [[Custodians|nine Custodians]] initially elected to serve in the Holy Land as interim head of the religion.<ref name="ency_custodians"/>
On 8 April 1960, Remey made a written announcement that he was the second Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith and explained his "status for life as commander in chief of Bahá’í affairs of the world" in this proclamation which he requested to be read in front of the annual US convention in [[Wilmette, Illinois|Wilmette]].<ref>See Charles Mason Remey, ''Proclamation to the Bahá'ís of the World'', p. 1 {{cite web |url=http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/1960_proclamation.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120062722/http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/1960_proclamation.htm |archivedate=2008-11-20}}</ref>
He based his claim on his having been appointed President of the first [[International Bahá'í Council]] by Shoghi Effendi in 1951.<ref name="ency_remey"/> The appointed council represented the first international Bahá'í body. Remey believed that his appointment as the council's president meant that he was the Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith.<ref name="ency_remey"/><ref>The Hands of the Cause wrote regarding his reasoning on this point, "If the President of the International Bahá'í Council is ''ipso facto'' the Guardian of the Bahá'í Faith, then the beloved Guardian, himself, Shoghi Effendi would have had to be the President of this first International Bahá'í Council." {{Harv|Rabbani|1992|p=234}} [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians&chapter=4]</ref>
Regarding the authority of the Hands of the Cause, Remey wrote in his letter that the Hands "have no authority vested in themselves... save under the direction of the living Guardian of the Faith."<ref>See Charles Mason Remey, ''Proclamation to the Bahá'ís of the World'', [http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/1960_proclamation.htm p. 5] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120062722/http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/1960_proclamation.htm |date=2008-11-20 }} and also "Role of the Hands of the Cause".</ref> He further commanded the Bahá'ís to abandon plans for establishing the Universal House of Justice.<ref>See Charles Mason Remey, ''Proclamation to the Bahá'ís of the World'', pp. 6-7 {{cite web |url=http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/1960_proclamation.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120062722/http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/1960_proclamation.htm |archivedate=2008-11-20}}</ref>
Remey never addressed the requirement that Guardians should be male-descendants of Bahá'u'lláh, of whom Remey was not. His followers later referred to letters and public statements of `Abdu'l-Bahá calling him "my son" as evidence that he had been implicitly adopted<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/index.htm |title=Brent Mathieu, ''Biography of Charles Mason Remey'' |access-date=2006-09-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060318131148/http://www.charlesmasonremey.net/index.htm |archive-date=2006-03-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> but these claims were almost universally rejected by the body of the Bahá'ís.<ref name="ency_hands"/>
In response, and after having made many prior efforts to convince Remey to withdraw his claim,<ref name="TCoB387">{{Harvnb|Taherzadeh|1992|p=387}}</ref><ref name="CoC370">{{Harvnb|Taherzadeh|2000|p=370}}</ref> the Custodians took action and sent a cablegram to the National Spiritual Assemblies on 26 July 1960.<ref>See {{Harv|Rabbani|1992|p=223}}</ref> Two days later the Custodians sent Mason Remey a letter informing him of their unanimous decision to declare him a Covenant-breaker.<ref name="ency_remey"/> They cited the Will and Testament of `Abdul-Bahá, the unanimous joint resolutions of November 25, 1957, and their authority in carrying out the work of the Guardian<ref name="LDG 82-83">See {{Harvnb|Effendi|1982|pp=82–83}} [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/LDG2/ldg2-95.html]</ref> as their justification. Anyone who accepted Remey's claim to the Guardianship was also expelled.<ref name="ency_remey"/>
Remey attracted about 100 followers in the United States and a few others in Pakistan and Europe.{{sfn|Gallagher|Ashcraft|2006|p=201}} Remey maintained his claim to Guardianship, and went on to establish what came to be known as the Orthodox Bahá'ís Under the Hereditary Guardianship, which later broke into several other divisions based on succession disputes within the groups that followed Remey.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/><ref name="ency_remeyite">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=292–293}}</ref> Although initially disturbing, the mainstream Bahá'ís paid little attention to his movement within a few years. As of 2006 his followers represent two or three groups that maintain little contact with each other, comprising a few hundred members collectively.{{sfn|Gallagher|Ashcraft|2006|p=201}}
===Decision of the Universal House of Justice=== [[File:firstUHJ.jpg|thumb|260px|right|Original members of the first Universal House of Justice, 1963.]] {{Main article|Universal House of Justice}} The Bahá'í institutions and believers around the world pledged their loyalty to the [[Hands of the Cause]], who dedicated the next few years to completing [[Shoghi Effendi|Shoghi Effendi's]] [[Ten Year Crusade]], culminating with the election of the Universal House of Justice in 1963. It was at this time the [[Custodians]] officially passed their authority as the head of the Faith to the Universal House of Justice,<ref name="ency_custodians"/><ref>{{harvnb|Smith|2008|p=68}}</ref> which soon announced that it could not appoint or legislate to make possible the appointment of a second Guardian to succeed Shoghi Effendi.<ref name="ency_house"/>
A short time later it elaborated on the situation in which the Guardian would die without being able to appoint a successor, saying that it was an obscure question not covered by Bahá'í scriptures, that no institution or individual at the time could have known the answer, and that it therefore had to be referred to the Universal House of Justice, whose election was confirmed by references in Shoghi Effendi's letters that after 1963 the Bahá'í world would be led by international plans under the direction of the Universal House of Justice.<ref>The Universal House of Justice, Letter of 9 March 1965, ''Messages from the Universal House of Justice, 1963-1986'', [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1963-86_full#s23.3 p. 50]</ref>
===A break in the line of Guardians=== Mason Remey and his successors asserted that a living Guardian is essential for the Bahá'í community, and that the Bahá'í writings required it. The basis of these claims were almost universally rejected by the body of the Bahá'ís,<ref name="ency_hands"/> for whom the restoration of scripturally sanctioned leadership of the Universal House of Justice proved more attractive than the claims of Mason Remey.<ref>{{Harvnb|Momen|Smith|1989|p=76}}</ref>
The House commented that its own authority was not dependent on the presence of a Guardian,<ref name="ency_house"/> and that its legislative functioning was unaffected by the absence of a Guardian.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> It stated that in its legislation it would be able to turn to the mass of interpretation left by Shoghi Effendi.<ref name="ency_guardianship"/> The Universal House of Justice addressed this issue further early after its election clarifying that "there is nowhere any promise or guarantee that the line of Guardians would endure forever; on the contrary there are clear indications that the line could be broken."<ref name="TCoB390">{{Harvnb|Taherzadeh|1992|p=390}}</ref><ref>The Universal House of Justice, Letter of 7 December 1969, ''Messages from the Universal House of Justice, 1963-1986'', [http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1963-86_full#s75.12 p. 158]</ref><ref>The Universal House of Justice specifically refers to [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-5.html#gr42 paragraph 42] of the [[Kitáb-i-Aqdas]] as evidence that Bahá'u'lláh anticipated that the line of Guardians was not guaranteed forever by providing for the disposition of the religion's endowments in the absence of the [[Aghsán]].{{Harv|Taherzadeh|1992|p=390}} See also Notes [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-83.html 66] and [http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/b/KA/ka-84.html 67] of the ''Kitáb-i-Aqdas'', pp. 196-197.</ref>
==Further development of Remey's followers== All those that professed belief in Mason Remey as the second Guardian did not accept the [[Universal House of Justice]] established in 1963.
Among the Bahá'ís who accepted Mason Remey as the second Guardian, several further divisions have occurred based on conflicting opinions of legitimacy and succession of authority.<ref name="Barrett p. 247"/><ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/> They began to split into smaller groups even before his death in 1974.<ref>{{Harvnb| Warburg |2004}} [http://www.signaturebooks.com/excerpts/Baha'i.htm]</ref> Small Remeyite groups are now largely confined to the United States.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/> Some of these divisions are described below.
The ''Encyclopædia Iranica'' reports the following: :Remey died in 1974, having appointed a third Guardian, but the number of adherents to the Orthodox faction remains extremely small. Although successful in Pakistan, the Remeyites seem to have attracted no followers in Iran. Other small groups have broken away from the main body from time to time, but none of these has attracted a sizeable following.<ref name="maceoin" />
Remey died at the age of 99 living many of his last years in Florence, Italy.<ref>{{cite web |title=Special Collections: Milton S. Eisenhower Library |publisher=The Johns Hopkins University |url=http://www.library.jhu.edu/collections/specialcollections/manuscripts/msregisters/ms375.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051024055044/http://www.library.jhu.edu/collections/specialcollections/manuscripts/msregisters/ms375.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-10-24 |accessdate=2007-09-26 |year=1995 |first=Joan |last=Grattan}}</ref>
===Under the Hereditary Guardianship=== In 1962 Mason Remey asked his supporters in the United States to organize themselves and elect a "National Spiritual Assembly Under the Hereditary Guardianship" (NSAUHG). The Assembly was incorporated in New Mexico in 1964.
In 1964 the NSAUHG filed a lawsuit against the National Spiritual Assembly (NSA) of the Bahá'ís of the United States to receive the legal title to the Bahá'í House of Worship in Illinois, and all other property owned by the NSA. The NSA counter-sued and won.<ref name="1966 court">[http://bahai-library.com/bahais_vs_new-mexico_covenant-breakers Bahá'ís vs New Mexico Group] District Court, N.D. Illinois, E. Div. No. 64 C 1878. Decided June 28, 1966</ref> Later that year, Remey asked the NSAUHG to dissolve, as well as the second International Bahá'í Council that he had appointed with Joel Marangella, residing in France, as president. Marangella, Donald Harvey, and Jacques Soghomonian had previously served on the National Spiritual Assembly of France (in 1961) and had been declared Covenant-breakers when they accepted Mason Remey as the next Guardian.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/>
After 1966, some followers of Mason Remey began forming their own groups based on different understandings of succession.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/>
===Orthodox Bahá'í Faith=== {{Main article| Orthodox Bahá'í Faith}}
Joel Marangella was president of Remey's "Second International Bahá'í Council", and claimed in 1969 to have been secretly appointed by Remey as Guardian several years earlier. His supporters came to be known as Orthodox Bahá'ís.<ref name="ency_remey" /> Membership data is scarce. One source estimated them at no more than 100 members in 1988,<ref>[http://www.momen.org/relstud/covenant.htm THE COVENANT], Moojan Momen. Quoting ''Chicago Tribune'', 10 June 1988, section 1, p. 9</ref> and the group claimed a United States membership of about 40 in a 2007 court case.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120219232042/http://www.truebahai.info/court/54-1-surreply-brief.pdf], US District Court for Northern District Court of Illinois Eastern Division, Civil Action No. 64 C 1878: Orthodox Bahá'í Respondents' Surreply Memorandum to NSA's Reply Memorandum, p2 para 2 line 15</ref> Websites claiming to represent the Orthodox community indicate followers in the United States and India.<ref>[http://www.orthodoxbahai.com The National Bahá'í Council of the Orthodox Bahá'í Faith]</ref> Joel Marangella died in San Diego, California on Sept 1, 2013.
===Bahá'ís Under the Provisions of the Covenant=== [[Leland Jensen]] accepted Remey's claim to the Guardianship and later left the group. In 1969 he was convicted of "a lewd and lascivious act" for sexually molesting a 15-year-old female patient,<ref>[https://www.fastcase.com/Yahoo/Start.aspx?C=26917489637405405daded611067aa76e77e8a5606aee00f&D=77eca924714beb4591a4da5747d53c9c77862a89c3a754d6&AffiliateConst=Yahoo ''State v. Jensen'', 153 Mont. 233, 455 P.2d 631 (Montana, 1969)]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and he served four years of a twenty-year sentence in the Montana State Prison. It was in prison that Jensen converted several inmates to his ideas of being what he called the "Establisher" of the Bahá'í Faith, stemming from his belief that the Bahá'í administrative order became corrupted. After being paroled in 1973 and before Remey's death, Jensen formed a group called the Bahá'ís Under the Provisions of the Covenant.<ref name="stone271">{{Harvnb|Stone|2000| p=271}}</ref>
Since the 1970s, Jensen believed Remey's adopted son Joseph Pepe was the Guardian, an idea that Pepe rejected several times. In 1991 Jensen appointed followers to a [[Bahá'ís Under the Provisions of the Covenant#sIBC|second International Bahá'í Council]] (sIBC), intending that it would grow into an elected Universal House of Justice after a [[nuclear holocaust]].<ref name="stone271" /> Jensen died in 1996.
A researcher has noted that since 1980 BUPC membership has never exceeded 200 nationwide,<ref name="stone271"/><ref>Harvard researchers have noted a community of 30 members in the headquarters of [[Missoula, Montana]] in 2003, as well as the existence of BUPC adherents in Denver and Alaska. ({{cite web |title=Bahá'í Faith Center |publisher=Harvard University, Committee on the Study of Religion |url=http://pluralism.org/profile/baha-i-faith-center-missoula/ |accessdate=2007-08-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927192448/http://www.pluralism.org/research/profiles/display.php?profile=72374 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |deadurl=no |df=}})({{cite web |title=Mapping Religious Diversity in Montana (2003) |publisher=Harvard University, Committee on the Study of Religion |url=http://www.pluralism.org/research/profiles/display.php?profile=73246 |accessdate=2007-08-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927192436/http://www.pluralism.org/research/profiles/display.php?profile=73246 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |deadurl=no |df=}})</ref> and declined in size significantly by 1990 and beyond.<ref name="stone280">{{harvnb|stone|2000|p=280}}</ref> Adherents were mostly concentrated in [[Montana]].<ref name="stone271"/>
===Jacques Soghomonian=== Donald Harvey (d.1991), was appointed by Remey as "Third Guardian" in 1967.<ref name="ency_remey" /> After Harvey's death in 1991, leadership of this group went to Jacques Soghomonian, a resident of Marseilles, France.<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/> Soghomonian died in 2013 and passed the successorship to E.S. Yazdani.<ref>http://guardianshipofthebahaifaith.org/ridvan/Ridvan%2020%20December%202013%20.pdf</ref>
===The Remey Society=== Francis Spataro of New York City, who supported Donald Harvey's claim as Remey's successor, independently organized "The Remey Society" after losing favor with Harvey. Spataro published books about Charles Mason Remey,<ref>*Spataro, Francis C. (2003). ''Charles Mason Remey and the Bahá'í Faith'', Tover Publications, Queens, NY 11427-2116. 2003 {{ISBN|0-9671656-3-6}}.</ref> and at one time had a newsletter with about 400 recipients. When Spataro began to preach that Charles Mason Remey was a "Prophet", Harvey cut all ties to Spataro. He then continued to promote the life and works of Charles Mason Remey. In 1995 Francis Spataro became an [[Old Catholic Church|Old Catholic]] priest and left the Bahá'í religion altogether. The Remey Society is now extinct.
==Other developments==
===Free Bahá'ís=== {{Main article| Free Bahá'ís}} The term '''Free Bahá'ís''' has been used by or about a small number of [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'ís]] that have attempted [[Bahá'í Faith|schism]] from the main body of believers of the Bahá'í Faith. More specifically, it is a form of belief that rejects the authority of [[Shoghi Effendi]], appointed in 1921 to lead the community following the death of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]].
The term was first used by [[Hermann Zimmer]], who revived the earlier claims of [[Ruth White (Bahá'í author)|Ruth White]] that the ''[[Will and Testament of `Abdu'l-Bahá]]'' was forged. White's claim was widely rejected by other Bahá'ís of the time, including Bahá'ís who, like her, were enemies of Shoghi Effendi.<ref name=Covenant>{{cite web |url=https://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_covenant |title=Covenant, The, and Covenant-breaker |last=Momen |first=Moojan |authorlink=Moojan Momen |date=1995 |website=Bahá'í Library Online |publisher=|access-date= December 22, 2016 |quote=}}</ref><ref name="child-covenant">{{cite book |last=Taherzadeh |first=Adib |authorlink=Adib Taherzadeh |year=2000 |title=The Child of the Covenant |publisher=George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK |isbn=0-85398-439-5 |pages=299–300}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The A to Z of the Baha'i Faith |first=Hugh C. |last=Adamson |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |year=2009 |isbn=0810868539 |p=121}}</ref><ref name="covenant-bahaullah">{{cite book |author=Taherzadeh, Adib |authorlink=Adib Taherzadeh |year=1972 |title=The Covenant of Bahá'u'lláh |publisher=George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK |isbn=0-85398-344-5 |page=347}}</ref> White was able to gather the support of a single Bahá'í in Germany, Wilhelm Herrigel, who took up her cause; only a few Bahá'ís followed him, and most repudiated him following his death in 1932.<ref name="balyuzi">{{cite book |title=Studies in Honor of the Late Hasan M. Balyuzi |chapter=Establishment of the Guardianship |last=Bramson-Lerche |first=Loni |editor=Moojan Momen |editorlink=Moojan Momen |date=1988 |publisher=Kalimát Press |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Rabbani, Ruhiyyih |authorlink=Rúhíyyih Khanum |year=1948 |title=Twenty-Five Years of the Guardianship |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |url=http://bahai-library.com/?file=khanum_25_years_guardianship#21 |page=21}}</ref>
===The Man=== "The House of Mankind and the Universal Palace of Order" followed Jamshid Ma'ani and John Carré, but appears now to be defunct. In the early 1970s a Persian man named Jamshid Ma'ani claimed he was "The Man"; or a new [[Manifestation of God]]. He gained a few dozen Iranian Bahá'í followers. John Carré heard of Jamshid, and wrote a book trying to get other Bahá'ís to accept a new, third Manifestation.<ref>See online at [http://www.maitreya.org/english/Other%20Evidences/Bahai/greatest_name.htm The third Manifestation of the Revelation of the Greatest Name, soon to appear]</ref> Carré even invited "The Man" to live in his home in California, but soon concluded, after living with "The Man" for four months, that "The Man" was not at all godly or spiritual and certainly not a Manifestation of God. "The Man" went back to Iran, and Carré ended all association with him.<ref name="Momen 2003 G.2.e" />
===Reginald ("Rex") King=== Rex King rejected all claimants to the Guardianship after Shoghi Effendi including Remey. He claimed that he, Rex King, was a "regent" pending the emergence of the second Guardian who was in "occultation". His group called themselves the Orthodox Bahá'í Faith under the Regency. King died in 1977 and appointed four of his family as the council of regents. This group today calls itself the "Tarbiyat Baha'i Community".<ref name = "Momen 2003 G.2.e"/>
