{{Infobox political party | name = Indonesian Christian Party | native_name = Partai Kristen Indonesia | native_name_lang = Indonesia | logo = IndonesianChristianParty.png | logo_size = 120px | colorcode = green | predecessor = National Christian Party | abbreviation = Parkindo | chairman = W. Z. Johanes | secretary_general = | founder = | founded = 10 November 1945 |dissolved = 11 January 1973 | merger = | merged = [[Indonesian Democratic Party]] | headquarters = Djakarta, Indonesia | ideology = [[Pancasila (politics)|Pancasila]]
[[Christianity]] | religion = [[Christianity]] ([[Protestantism|Protestant]]) | affiliation1_title = | affiliation1 = | colors = | country = Indonesia | footnotes = }}'''Parkindo''' ({{lang-id|Partai Kristen Indonesia}}, Indonesian Christian Party) was a political party in [[Indonesia]] from 1950 to 1973. Founded by Johannes Leimena and Melanchton Siregar, the former Military Governor of North Sumatra, who has known as a local teacher in Tarutung. Its support was concentrated in [[Protestant]] areas of Indonesia. It had considerable influence despite the small number of Christians in Indonesia due to the large numbers of Christians in the civil service, the [[Indonesian Army|Army]] and educational establishments and because of the high profile of party leader [[Johannes Leimena]] who served in several [[cabinet of Indonesia|Indonesian cabinets]] and as deputy prime minister.Feith (2007) p145 In the [[Indonesian legislative election, 1955|1955 Indonesian legislative election]], the party won 2.6% of the vote and eight seats in the [[People's Representative Council]].Feith (2007) p434 However, in the [[Indonesian legislative election, 1971|1971 elections]], the last it contested before being merged into the [[Indonesian Democratic Party]], it gained only 1.34% of the vote.Evans (2003) pp. 21-21Liddle (1994) p46 ==References== * Evans, Kevin Raymond, (2003) ''The History of Political Parties & General Elections in Indonesia'', Arise Consultancies, Jakarta, {{ISBN|979-97445-0-4}} * [[Herbert Feith|Feith, Herbert]] (2007) ''The Decline of Constitutional Democracy in Indonesia '' Equinox Publishing (Asia) Pte Ltd, {{ISBN|978-979-3780-45-0}} * Liddle, R. William (1994) ''Pemilu-Pemilu Orde Baru (Elections of the New Order)'', LP3ES, Jakarta {{ISBN|978-979-8015-88-5}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} {{Former Indonesian political parties}} [[Category:1945 establishments in Indonesia]] [[Category:1973 disestablishments in Indonesia]] [[Category:Christian political parties]] [[Category:Christianity in Indonesia]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Indonesia]] [[Category:Political parties disestablished in 1973]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1945]] {{Indonesia-party-stub}}

{{Infobox Officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[General]] [[Kaji (Nepal)|Kaji]] |name=Ranabir Singh Thapa |native_name =श्री जनरल काजी
रणवीर सिंह थापा |image= Ranabir Singh Thapa.jpg |caption= Portrait of Kaji General Ranabir Singh Thapa |father= [[Amar Singh Thapa (born 1759)|Amar Singh Thapa (sanu)]] |mother= Satyarupa Maya |office ='''Acting Mukhtiyar''' (Acting PM) of Nepal{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=157}} |predecessor =[[Bhimsen Thapa]] |successor = [[Bhimsen Thapa]] |relations= see [[Thapa dynasty]] |rank= [[General]] |allegiance= {{flag|Nepal}} |battles = [[Anglo-Nepalese war]] |commands =Kalibaksh Battalion, Shree Sabuj Battalion }} '''Ranabir Singh Thapa''' ({{lang-ne|रणवीर सिंह थापा}}) also spelled '''Ranbir''', '''Ranavir''' or '''Ranvir''' also known by the late ascetic name '''Swami Abhayananda''' ({{lang-ne|स्वामी अभयानन्द}}) was a Nepalese Army General, prominent politician and minister of state. In 1837, he became Acting [[Mukhtiyar]] (equivalent to Prime Minister) of Nepal for a brief period. He was a prominent member of [[Thapa dynasty]]. He later turned ascetic and was known by the [[Sanyasi]] name Swami Abhayananda. ==Early Life== {{main|Thapa dynasty}} Ranabir Singh was born as the youngest son of [[Amar Singh Thapa (born 1759)|''Sanukaji'' Amar Singh Thapa]] and Satyarupa Maya.{{sfn|Pradhan|2012|pp=22-23}} He was the brother of [[Mukhtiyar]] [[Bhimsen Thapa]].{{sfn|Pradhan|2012|p=23}} ==Life as politician and military officer== He was the Commander of the Makwanpur-Hariharpur axis during [[Anglo-Nepalese war]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nepalarmy.mil.np/history.php?page=two|publisher=nepalarmy.mil.np|title=Nepalese Army | नेपाली सेना|accessdate=2016-10-05}} In 1871 BS (1814 AD) he was deputed to Makwanpur to command the troops. He was leading 4000 soldiers against Major General Marley and Major General Woods. They were lured to major killing area by Ranabir Singh but Major-General Woods did not advance from Bara Gadhi. After the war he became the administrator of Palpa and the general of Kalibash and Sabuj battalion. [[File:Ranabir Singh Thapa letter.gif|thumb|Outer cover of letter sent by General Ranabir Singh Thapa signed by his private black seal to PM Bhimsen Thapa and Kazi [[Ranadhoj Thapa]] in Kantipur (Kathmandu)http://www.bilder-aus-nepal.de/Pages/Philatelie/Thapa-Brief/Thapa-Brief-1835.html]] He was appointed chief member at the Royal Palace to keep observation on the King and Queen.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=148}} After the death of [[Queen Tripurasundari of Nepal]], the royal seal by which government orders were approved naturally went into the hands of the senior queen [[Samrajya Lakshmi Devi]], who knew all too well of its powers and wanted to emulate the queens of the past by establishing her own regency.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=149}}{{sfn|Pradhan|2012|p=156}} Sensing Samrajya Laxmi's ambition, Ranbir Singh started to stroke her dislike of Bhimsen in the hopes of becoming the ''[[Mukhtiyar]]'' himself.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=149}} There was a quarrel between [[Mathabar Singh Thapa]] and Ranabir Singh regarding the latter's loyalty shift towards the senior Queen Samrajya Lakshmi resulting in Mathabar resigning from the commandership of Sri Nath Regiment.{{sfn|Pradhan|2012|p=147}} Getting a whiff of this matter, Bhimsen strongly reprimanded Ranbir Singh which caused him to resign from his General's position and live in retirement in his house at Sipamandan.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|pp=149–150}} However, Bhimsen later managed to placate his brother, by giving him the title of Chota (Little) General, and send him to Palpa as its governor.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=151}}{{sfn|Pradhan|2012|p=148}} King Rajendra supported Bhimsen instead of Ranabir Singh and the removal of Ranabir Singh sabotaged the Queen's plan.{{sfn|Pradhan|2012|p=148}} In April 1835, Bhimsen also hatched a plan to make a state visit to Britain, hoping to force Britain to acknowledge the sovereignty of Nepal; but since he could not make the visit himself, his nephew Colonel Mathabar Singh Thapa was chosen as the representative of Nepal, bearing a few gifts and a letter from King Rajendra addressed to King William IV.{{sfn|Nepal|2007|p=104}}{{sfn|Rana|1988|p=18}}{{sfn|Acharya|2012|pp=152–153}} In this process, Ranbir Singh, the governor of Palpa, was made Full General beside the promotion of Mathabar Singh Thapa and Sher Jung Thapa.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|pp=152–153}} After the annual muster at the beginning of 1837, an investigation was also started to check Bhimsen's expenditures in establishing various battalions.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=156}} Such events led the courtiers to feel that Bhimsen's ''Mukhtiyari'' would not last very long; thus Ranbir Singh Thapa, in the hopes of becoming the next ''[[Mukhtiyar]]'', wrote a letter to the King asking him to be recalled to Kathmandu from Palpa. His wish was granted; and Bhimsen, pleased to see his brother after many years, made Ranbir Singh the acting ''Mukhtiyar'' and decided to go to his ancestral home in Borlang Gorkha for the sake of pilgrimage.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=157}} On 24 July 1837, Rajendra's youngest son, Devendra Bikram Shah, an infant of six months, died suddenly.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=158}}{{sfn|Nepal|2007|p=105}} It was at once rumored that the child had died of poison intended for his mother the Senior Queen Samrajya Laxmi Devi: given at the instigation of Bhimsen, or someone of his party.{{sfn|Nepal|2007|p=105}}{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=159}}{{sfn|Whelpton|2004|pp=28–29}} On this charge, Bhimsen, his brother Ranbir Singh, his nephew Mathbar Singh, their families, the court physicians, Ekdev and Eksurya Upadhyay, and his deputy Bhajuman Baidya, with a few more of the nearest relatives of the Thapas were incarcerated, proclaimed outcasts, and their properties confiscated.{{sfn|Nepal|2007|p=105}}{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=159}}{{sfn|Acharya|1971|p=13}}{{sfn|Oldfield|1880|p=310}} ==Release and ascetic life== Fearful that the Pandes would re-establish their power, [[Fateh Jung Shah|Fatte Jang Shah]], Ranganath Poudel, and the Junior Queen Rajya Laxmi Devi obtained from the King the liberation of Bhimsen, Mathabar, and the rest of the party, about eight months after they were incarcerated for the poisoning case.{{sfn|Oldfield|1880|p=311}}{{sfn|Nepal|2007|p=109}}{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=161}} Sensing that a catastrophe was going to befall the Thapas, Mathabar Singh fled to India while pretending to go on a hunting trip; Ranbir Singh gave up all his property and became a [[sannyas|sanyasi]], titling himself Abhayanand Puri; but Bhimsen Thapa preferred to remain in his old home in Gorkha.{{sfn|Acharya|2012|p=161}}{{sfn|Nepal|2007|p=110}} He was rendered by the following full name in his ascetic life '''Shreemant Paramahamsa Paribrajakacharya Swami Abhayananda Giri Nepali'''. ==Gallery== File:Ranabir Singh Thapa as Swami Abhayananda.jpg|thumb|Ranabir Singh Thapa as Swami Abhayananda ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== *{{citation | last = Pradhan | first = Kumar L. | title = Thapa Politics in Nepal: With Special Reference to Bhim Sen Thapa, 1806–1839 | publisher = Concept Publishing Company | year = 2012 | isbn = 9788180698132 | location = New Delhi | pages = 278 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7PP1yElRzIUC&dq=the+assassination+of+rana+bahadur+shah&source=gbs_navlinks_s }} *{{citation | last = Acharya | first = Baburam | editor-last = Acharya | editor-first = Shri Krishna |title = Janaral Bhimsen Thapa : Yinko Utthan Tatha Pattan | location = Kathmandu | year = 2012 | pages = 228 | language = Nepali | publisher = Education Book House | isbn = 9789937241748}} *{{citation | last = Nepal | first = Gyanmani | title = Nepal ko Mahabharat | publisher = Sajha | language = Nepali | year = 2007 | edition = 3rd | pages = 314 | location = Kathmandu | isbn = 9789993325857 }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thapa, Ranabir Singh}} [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Nepalese military personnel]] [[Category:Nepalese politicians]] [[Category:People of the Gurkha War]] [[Category:Gurkhas]] [[Category:History of Nepal]] [[Category:Thapa dynasty]] [[Category:People from Gorkha District]] [[Category:Bagale Thapa]] [[Category:Hindu warriors]] [[Category:Yogis]] [[Category:Spiritual teachers]] [[Category:Hindu mystics]] {{Nepal-bio-stub}} {{Asia-mil-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: /* 1800s to 1900s */ This is a better image
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = Religion in Canada (2011 National Household Survey){{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/130508/dq130508b-eng.htm?HPA |title=Religions in Canada—Census 2011 |publisher=Statistics Canada/Statistique Canada}} |label1 = [[Roman Catholicism in Canada|Roman Catholicism]] |value1 = 39.0 |color1 = Darkblue |label2 = Other [[Christianity in Canada|Christian]]Of whom 27% [[Protestantism in Canada|Protestant]] and 1.5% other Christians, see [http://www.pewforum.org/2013/06/27/canadas-changing-religious-landscape/ Canada's Changing Religious Landscape] |value2 = 28.3 |color2 = DodgerBlue |label3 = [[Irreligion in Canada|Non-religious]] |value3 = 23.9 |color3 = Honeydew |label4 = [[Islam in Canada|Islam]] |value4 = 3.2 |color4 = Green |label5 = [[Hinduism in Canada|Hinduism]] |value5 = 1.5 |color5 = Orange |label6 = [[Sikhism in Canada|Sikhism]] |value6 = 1.4 |color6 = DarkKhaki |label7 = [[Buddhism in Canada|Buddhism]] |value7 = 1.1 |color7 = Yellow |label8 = [[Judaism in Canada|Judaism]] |value8 =1.0 |color8 = DarkBlue |label9 = Other religions |value9 = 0.6 |color9 = Chartreuse }} [[File:Iqaluit St. Jude's Anglican Cathedral 2012.JPG|thumb|[[St. Jude's Cathedral (Iqaluit)|St. Jude's Cathedral]] ([[Anglican Church of Canada|Anglican]]) in [[Iqaluit]], [[Nunavut]].]] '''Religion in Canada''' encompasses a wide range of groups and beliefs.{{cite book|author1=Dianne R. Hales|author2=Lara Lauzon|title=An Invitation to Health|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O3Y9-P_Sj7oC&pg=PA440|year=2009|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=978-0-17-650009-2|page=440}} Christianity is the largest religion in [[Canada]], with [[Roman Catholic]]s having the most adherents. Christians, representing 67.3% of the population in 2011, are followed by people having [[irreligion|no religion]] with 23.9% of the total population. Other faiths include [[Islam|Muslims]] (3.2%), [[Hinduism in Canada|Hindus]] (1.5%), [[Sikhs]] (1.4%), [[Buddhism|Buddhists]] (1.1%), and [[Jew]]s (1.0%).{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/130508/dq130508b-eng.htm?HPA|title=The Daily – 2011 National Household Survey: Immigration, place of birth, citizenship, ethnic origin, visible minorities, language and religion|work=Statistics Canada}} Rates of religious adherence are steadily decreasing.{{cite web |url= http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/resources/countries/canada |title=Canada |work= |publisher=[[Berkley Center for Religion, Peace, and World Affairs]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}{{cite book|author1=J. Gordon Melton|author2=Martin Baumann|title=Religions of the World, Second Edition: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&pg=PA493|year=2010|isbn=978-1-59884-204-3|page=493}} The [[preamble to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] refers to God. The [[Monarchy of Canada|monarch]] carries the title of "[[Fidei defensor|Defender of the Faith]]". However, Canada has no [[official religion]], and support for [[religious pluralism]] and [[Freedom of religion in Canada|freedom of religion]] is an important part of [[Political culture of Canada|Canada's political culture]].{{cite web|url=http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/charter/1.html#anchorbo-ga:l_I-gb|title=Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (Part I of the Constitution Act, 1982)|publisher=Department of Justice Canada|year=2010|accessdate=September 10, 2010}}{{cite book|author=Gary Miedema|title=For Canada's Sake: Public Religion, Centennial Celebrations, and the Re-making of Canada in the 1960s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0q8OSvcfqBkC&pg=PR15|year=2005|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=978-0-7735-2877-2|page=15}} Before the European colonization, [[Native American religion|Aboriginal religions]] were largely [[animist]]ic or [[shamanist]]ic, including an intense tribal reverence for [[spirit]]s and nature.Native North American Religious Traditions: Dancing for Life – Page 5, Jordan D. Paper – 2007 The [[French colonization of the Americas|French colonization]] beginning in the 17th century established a Roman Catholic [[French language|francophone]] population in [[New France]], especially [[Acadia]] (later [[Lower Canada]], now [[Nova Scotia]] and [[Quebec]]). [[British colonization of the Americas|British colonization]] brought waves of [[Anglicans]] and other [[Protestants]] to [[Upper Canada]], now [[Ontario]]. The [[Russian Empire]] spread [[Orthodox Christianity]] in a small extent to the tribes in the far north and western coasts, particularly hyperborean nomadics like the [[Inuit]]; Orthodoxy would arrive to the mainland with immigrants from the [[Soviet Union]], [[Eastern Bloc]], [[Greece]] and elsewhere during the 20th century. With Christianity in decline after having once been central and integral to Canadian culture and daily life,{{cite book|author=Lance W. Roberts|title=Recent Social Trends in Canada, 1960–2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qnPOqwsR5UsC&pg=PA359|year=2005|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=978-0-7735-2955-7|page=359}} Canada has become a [[Postchristianity|post-Christian]], [[secularity|secular]] state{{cite book|author1=Paul Bramadat|author2=David Seljak|title=Religion and Ethnicity in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VymssyK1Hs0C&pg=PA3|year=2009|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-1018-7|page=3}}{{cite book|author=Kurt Bowen|title=Christians in a Secular World: The Canadian Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=__38sGZLrvYC&pg=PA174|year=2004|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=978-0-7735-7194-5|page=174}}{{cite book|author1=Derek Gregory|author2=Ron Johnston|author3=Geraldine Pratt |author4=Michael Watts |author5=Sarah Whatmore|title=The Dictionary of Human Geography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5liCbG4J9LYC&pg=PT672|year=2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-4443-1056-6|page=672}} despite the majority of Canadians claiming an affiliation with Christianity.{{Cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/130508/dq130508b-eng.htm?HPA|title=The Daily – 2011 National Household Survey: Immigration, place of birth, citizenship, ethnic origin, visible minorities, language and religion|last=Canada|first=Government of Canada, Statistics|website=www.statcan.gc.ca|access-date=December 3, 2017}} The majority of Canadians consider [[Importance of religion by country|religion to be unimportant]] in their daily lives,{{cite book|author=Betty Jane Punnett|title=International Perspectives on Organizational Behavior and Human Resource Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tG2mBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA116|year=2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-46745-8|page=116}} but still believe in God.{{cite book|author=Dr. David M. Haskell (Wilfrid Laurier University)|title=Through a Lens Darkly: How the News Media Perceive and Portray Evangelicals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TzJMfNOR5O0C&pg=PA50|year=2009|publisher=Clements Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-894667-92-0|page=50}} The practice of religion is now generally considered a private matter throughout society and the state.{{cite book|author1=Kevin Boyle|author2=Juliet Sheen|title=Freedom of Religion and Belief: A World Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JxgFWwK8dXwC&pg=PT219|year=2013|publisher=University of Essex – Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-72229-7|page=219}} ==Government and religion== {{main|Freedom of religion in Canada}} Canada today has no official church, and the [[Government of Canada|government]] is officially committed to [[religious pluralism]].{{cite book|author=Richard Moon|title=Law and Religious Pluralism in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ah66SQsk4hAC&pg=PA1|year= 2008|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-1497-3|pages=1–4}} While the Canadian government's official ties to religion, specifically [[Christianity]] are few, the [[Preamble to the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] makes reference to "the supremacy of God.{{cite book|title=Religion as a Category of Governance and Sovereignty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MVLFCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA284|date=27 May 2015|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-29059-4|pages=284–}} The [[O Canada|national anthem]] in both [[Official bilingualism in Canada|official languages]] also refers to God.{{cite book|author=Philip Resnick|title=The Labyrinth of North American Identities|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aMhYBZINycsC&pg=PA17|year=2012|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-1-4426-0552-7|pages=17–}} Nevertheless, the rise of [[Irreligion in Canada|irreligion]] within the country and influx of non-Christian peoples has led to a greater separation of government and religion,{{cite book|author1=Lance W. Roberts|author2=Rodney A. Clifton|author3=Barry Ferguson|title=Recent Social Trends in Canada, 1960–2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qnPOqwsR5UsC&pg=PA359|year= 2005|publisher=McGill-Queens|isbn=978-0-7735-2955-7|page=359}} demonstrated in forms like "Christmas holidays" being called "winter festivals" in public schools.{{cite book|author=Marguerite Van Die|title=Religion and Public Life in Canada: Historical and Comparative Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GxZqGT-IrJ4C&pg=PA289|year= 2001|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-8245-9|page=289}} Some religious schools are government-funded as per [[Section Twenty-nine of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]].{{cite book|author1=Anne F. Bayefsky|author2=Arieh Waldman|title=State Support of Religious Education: Canada Versus the United Nations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dAE5Bmw2qrEC&pg=PA3|year=2007|publisher=Martinus Nijhoff Publishers|isbn=978-90-04-14980-9|page=3}} [[File:Canadian Parliament Centre Block showing winter decorations.jpg|thumb| [[Centre Block]] of the [[Canadian Parliament]] in Ottawa showing Christmas decorations.]] Canada is a [[Commonwealth realm]] in which the [[head of state]] is shared with 15 other countries. As such, Canada follows the United Kingdom's succession laws for its monarch, which bar [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholics]] from inheriting the throne.{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/28/uk-royal-succession-rules_n_1064062.html | work=Huffington Post | title=U.K. Royal Succession Rules To Change | date=October 28, 2011}} Within Canada, the Queen's title includes the phrases "By the Grace of God" and "[[Fidei defensor|Defender of the Faith]]."{{cite book|author=Robert A. Battram|title=Canada in Crisis...: An Agenda to Unify the Nation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z3fp-S2_c7kC&pg=PA86|year=2010|publisher=Trafford Publishing|isbn=978-1-4269-8062-6|page=86}} [[Christmas]] and [[Easter]] are nationwide holidays, and while [[Judaism|Jews]], [[Islam|Muslims]], and other religious groups are allowed to take their holy days off work, they do not share the same official recognition.{{cite book|author=[[Kevin Boyle (lawyer)|Kevin Boyle]]|title=Freedom of Religion and Belief: A World Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MFUZkWWgOtMC&pg=PA103|year=1997|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-15978-4|page=103}} In 1957, the [[Parliament of Canada|Parliament]] declared [[Thanksgiving (Canada)|Thanksgiving]] "a day of general thanksgiving to almighty God for the bountiful harvest with which Canada has been blessed."{{cite book|author1=Erwin Fahlbusch|author2=Geoffrey William Bromiley|title=The Encyclopedia of Christianity: E-I. Volume 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yaecVMhMWaEC&pg=PA501|year=1999|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-90-04-11695-5|page=501}} There was an ongoing battle in the late 20th century to have religious garb accepted throughout Canadian society, mostly focused on [[Sikh]] [[turban]]s. The Canadian Armed Forces authorized the wearing of turban in 1986, eventually the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] followed in 1988 and eventually other federal government agencies accepted members wearing turbans. ==Census results== In the [[Canada 2011 National Household Survey]] (the 2011 census did not ask about religious affiliation but the survey sent to a subset of the population did), 67% of the Canadian population list [[Roman Catholicism]] or [[Protestantism]] or another [[List of Christian denominations|Christian denomination]] as their religion, considerably less than 10 years before in the [[Canada 2001 Census]], where 77% of the population listed a Christian religion.{{cite web |url=http://www40.statcan.gc.ca/l01/cst01/demo30c-eng.htm |title=Summary Tables |publisher=0.statcan.gc.ca |accessdate=October 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205182419/http://www40.statcan.gc.ca/l01/cst01/demo30c-eng.htm |archivedate=February 5, 2012 }} {{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/products/analytic/companion/rel/contents.cfm |title=96F0030XIE2001015 – Religions in Canada |publisher=2.statcan.ca |accessdate=October 17, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/can_rel1.htm |title=Christian religious data from Canada |publisher=Religioustolerance.org |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} Representing two out of five Canadians, the [[Roman Catholic Church in Canada]] is by far the country's largest single denomination. Secularization has been growing since the 1960s.Hans Mol, "The secularization of Canada." ''Research in the social scientific study of religion'' (1989) 1:197–215.{{cite book|author=Mark A. Noll|title=A History of Christianity in the United States and Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VGF3wbzzy9QC&pg=PR15|year=1992|pages=15–17}} In 2011, 23.9% declared [[Irreligion|no religious affiliation]], compared to 16.5% in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/15/no-religion-is-increasingly-popular-for-canadians-report_n_3283268.html|title='No Religion' Is Increasingly Popular For Canadians: Report|work=Huffington Post|date=May 15, 2013|accessdate=May 19, 2013}} In recent years there have been substantial rises in non-Christian religions in Canada. From the 1991 to 2011, [[Islam]] grew by 316%, [[Hinduism]] 217%, [[Sikhism]] 209%, and [[Buddhism]] 124%. The growth of non-Christian religions expressed as a percentage of Canada's population rose from 4% in 1991 to 8% in 2011. In terms of the ratio of non-Christians to Christians, it rose from 21 Christians (95% of religious population) to 1 non-Christian (5% of religious population) in 1991 to 8 Christians (89%) to 1 non-Christian (11%) in 2011, a rise of 135% of the ratio of non-Christians to Christians, or a decline of 6.5% of Christians to non-Christians, in 20 years. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |+ Religious denominations in Canada |- | rowspan=2 | ! style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|19911 ! style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|20012 ! style="text-align:center;" colspan="2"|20113 |- ! Retrieved April 24, 2014 ==History== {{see also|History of freedom of religion in Canada}} ===Before 1800s=== {{see also|Mythologies of the indigenous peoples of North America|Native American religion}} [[File:Le Grand Voyage du Pays des Hurons 1632 Gabriel Sagard.jpg|thumb|''Le Grand Voyage du Pays des Hurons'', [[Gabriel Sagard]], 1632.]] Before the arrival of Europeans, the [[First Nations]] followed a wide array of mostly [[animistic]] religions and spirituality.{{cite book|author=James Rodger Miller|title=Skyscrapers Hide the Heavens: A History of Indian-white Relations in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eGXeFCkTmlgC&pg=PA62|year=2000|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-8153-7|page=62}}{{cite book|author=Elizabeth Tooker|title=Native North American spirituality of the eastern woodlands: sacred myths, dreams, visions, speeches, healing formulas, rituals, and ceremonials|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LBKoyY455PQC&pg=PA20|year=1979|publisher=Paulist Press|isbn=978-0-8091-2256-1|page=20}} The first Europeans to settle in great numbers in Canada were [[France|French]] [[Latin Rite]] [[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholics]], including a large number of [[Society of Jesus|Jesuits]] who established several [[Jesuit missions in North America|missions in North America]]. They were dedicated to converting the Natives; an effort that eventually proved successful.{{cite book|author=Thomas Guthrie Marquis|title=The Jesuit Missions: A Chronicle of the Cross in the Wilderness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3JUafxF4tdEC&pg=PA7|year=1935|publisher=Hayes Barton Press|isbn=978-1-59377-530-8|pages=7–13}} The first large [[Protestantism|Protestant]] communities were formed in the [[The Maritimes|Maritimes]] after they were conquered by the [[United Kingdom|British]].{{cite book|author1=Roderick MacLeod|author2=Mary Anne Poutanen|title=Meeting of the People: School Boards and Protestant Communities in Quebec, 1801B1998|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K_tfubwEbb0C&pg=PA23|year= 2004|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-7183-9|page=23}} Unable to convince enough British immigrants to go to the region, the government decided to import continental Protestants from [[Germany]] and [[Switzerland]] to populate the region and counterbalance the Roman Catholic [[Acadians]].{{cite book|author1=Will Kaufman|author2=Heidi Slettedahl Macpherson|title=Britain and the Americas: Culture, Politics, And History: A Multidesciplinary Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HbBbn3x7PZsC&pg=PA13|year=2005|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-85109-431-8|page=13}} This group was known as the [[Foreign Protestants]]. This effort proved successful and today the [[South Shore (Nova Scotia)|South Shore]] region of [[Nova Scotia]] is still largely [[Lutheranism|Lutheran]]. After the [[Expulsion of the Acadians]] beginning in 1755 a large number of [[New England Planters]] settled on the vacated lands bringing with them their [[Congregationalist]] belief.{{cite book|author1=Terrence Murphy|author2=Roberto Perin|title=A concise history of Christianity in Canada|year=1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-540758-7|page=129}} During the 1770s, guided by [[Henry Alline]], the [[New Light]] movement of the [[Great Awakening]] swept through the [[Atlantic Canada|Atlantic region]] converting many of the Congregationalists to the new theology.{{cite book|author=Daniel Vickers|title=A Companion to Colonial America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8XcQUcweabUC&pg=PA503|year=2008|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-99848-9|page=503}} After Alline's death many of these Newlights eventually became [[Baptists]], thus making Maritime Canada the heartland of the [[Baptism|Baptist movement]] in Canada.Beverley, James and Barry Moody, Editors. The Journal of Henry Alline. Lancelot Press for the Acadia Divinity School and the Baptist Historical Committee. 1982.Bumsted, J. M. Henry Alline. Lancelot Press, Hantsport, 1984.Rawlyk, George. The Sermons of Henry Alline. Lancelot Press for Acadia Divinity College and The Baptist Historical Committee of the United Baptist Convention of the Atlantic Provinces. 1986. The [[Quebec Act]] of 1774 acknowledged the rights of the Roman Catholic Church throughout [[Lower Canada]] in order to keep the [[French Canadian]]s loyal to [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Britannic Crown]].{{cite book|author1=Charles H Lippy|author2=Peter W Williams|title=Encyclopedia of Religion in America|volume=4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BN7wAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT408|year=2010|publisher=Granite Hill Publishers|isbn=978-0-87289-580-5|page=408}} Roman Catholicism is still the main religion of French Canadians today. [[File:St Pauls, Halifax.JPG|thumb|[[St. Paul's Church (Halifax)|St. Paul's Church]], [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], the oldest [[Anglican]] church in Canada still standing, built in 1750.]] The [[American Revolution]] beginning in 1765 brought a large influx of Protestants to Canada when [[United Empire Loyalists]], fleeing the rebellious [[United States]], moved in large numbers to Upper Canada and the Maritimes.{{cite book|author=Oxford University Press|title=Protestantism: Oxford Bibliographies Online Research Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B_ZwQwK7c7wC&pg=PA16|year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-980853-3|page=16}} They comprised a mix of Christian groups with a large number of [[Anglican Church of Canada|Anglicans]], but also many [[Presbyterians]] and [[Methodists]]. ===1800s to 1900s=== While [[Anglicanism|Anglicans]] consolidated their hold on the upper classes, workingmen and farmers responded to the [[Methodism|Methodist revivals]], often sponsored by visiting preachers from the [[United States]]. Typical was Rev. [[James Caughey]], an American sent by the [[Wesleyan Church|Wesleyan Methodist Church]] from the 1840s through 1864. He brought in the converts by the score, most notably in the revivals in Western Canada from 1851 to 1853. His technique combined restrained emotionalism with a clear call for personal commitment, coupled with follow-up action to organize support from converts. It was a time when the [[holiness movement]] caught fire, with the revitalized interest of men and women in [[Christian perfection]]. Caughey successfully bridged the gap between the style of earlier camp meetings and the needs of more sophisticated Methodist congregations in the emerging cities.Peter Bush, "The Reverend James Caughey and Wesleyan Methodist Revivalism in Canada West, 1851–1856," ''Ontario History,'' Sept 1987, Vol. 79 Issue 3, pp 231–250 In the early nineteenth century in the [[The Maritimes|Maritimes]] and [[Upper Canada]], the [[Anglican Church of Canada|Anglican Church]] held the same official position it did in [[England]]. This caused tension within [[English Canada]], as much of the populace was not Anglican. Increasing immigration from [[Scotland]] created a very large [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] community and they and other groups demanded equal rights. This was an important cause of the [[1837 Rebellion in Upper Canada]]. With the arrival of [[Responsible government#Canada|responsible governments]], the Anglican monopoly was ended.{{cite book|author1=Charles H.H. Scobie|author2=George A. Rawlyk|title=Contribution of Presbyterianism to the Maritime Provinces of Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HpHeYb3YTWYC&pg=PP1|year=1997|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-1600-7|page=(page(s) needed)}} In [[Lower Canada]], the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic Church]] was officially pre-eminent and had a central role in the colony's culture and politics. Unlike English Canada, [[French Canadian]] [[Quebec nationalism|nationalism]] became very closely associated with Roman Catholicism.{{cite web |url= http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/resources/countries/canada |title=Canada |work= |publisher=[[Berkley Center for Religion, Peace, and World Affairs]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} See drop-down essay on "Early European Settlement and the Formation of the Modern State" During this period, the Roman Catholic Church in the region became one of the most reactionary in the world. Known as [[Ultramontane]] Catholicism, the church adopted positions condemning all manifestations of [[liberalism]].{{cite book|author=Raymond J. Lahey|title=The First Thousand Years: A Brief History of the Catholic Church in Canada|year=2002|publisher=Novalis Publishing|isbn=978-2-89507-235-5}} In politics, those aligned with the Roman Catholic clergy in [[Quebec]] were known as ''[[parti bleu|les bleus]]'' (the blues). They formed a curious alliance with the staunchly monarchist and pro-British Anglicans of English Canada (often members of the [[Orange Institution|Orange Order]]) to form the basis of the Canadian [[Conservative Party of Canada (historical)|Conservative Party]]. The [[Reform Party of Canada|Reform Party]], which later became the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]], was largely composed of the anti-clerical French Canadians, known as ''[[parti rouge|les rouges]]'' (the reds) and the non-Anglican [[Protestantism|Protestant]] groups. In those times, right before elections, parish priests would give sermons to their flock where they said things like ''Le ciel est bleu et l'enfer est rouge'' ("Heaven/the sky is blue and hell is red"). In 1871, national census revealed 56.45% as Protestants, 42.80% as Roman Catholic, 0.05% as Pagans, 0.03% as Jewish, 0.02% as Mormons, 0.15% as irreligious and 0.49% as unspecified.https://www66.statcan.gc.ca/eng/1922-23/192202030163_p.%20163.pdf By the late nineteenth century, Protestant pluralism had taken hold in English Canada. While much of the elite were still Anglican, other groups, including the Methodists, had become very prominent as well. The schools and universities created at this time reflected this pluralism with major centres of learning being established for each faith. One, King's College, later the [[University of Toronto]], was set up as a non-denominational school. The influence of the Orange Order was strong, especially among [[Protestantism in Ireland|Irish Protestant]] immigrants, and comprised a powerful anti-Catholic force in [[Ontario]] politics; its influence faded away after 1920.{{cite book|author1=Cecil J. Houston|author2=William J. Smyth|title=The sash Canada wore: a historical geography of the Orange Order in Canada|year=1980|publisher=University of Toronto Press}} The late nineteenth century also saw the beginning of a large shift in Canadian immigration patterns. Large numbers of [[Irish Canadians|Irish]] and [[Southern Europe]]an immigrants were creating new Roman Catholic communities in English Canada. Western Canada saw the arrival of significant [[Eastern Orthodox]] immigrants from [[Eastern Europe]] as well as [[Mormon]] and [[Pentecostal]] immigrants from the United States and [[Ireland]]. [[File:Basílica de Notre-Dame, Montreal, Canadá, 2017-08-11, DD 26-28 HDR.jpg|thumb|[[Notre-Dame Basilica (Montreal)|Notre-Dame Basilica]] ([[Catholic]]) in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]].]] ===1900s to 1960s=== {|class="wikitable" style="float:right; margin-left:1em;" !Denomination !Population, 1951 census{{cite web|title=Table A164-184, Principal religious denominations of the population, census dates 1871 to 1971|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/access_acces/archive.action?l=eng&loc=A164_184-eng.csv|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=November 18, 2016}} !% of total |- |[[Catholic Church in Canada|Roman Catholic]] |align="right"|6,069,496 |align="right"|43.3% |- |[[United Church of Canada|United Church]] |align="right"|2,867,271 |align="right"|20.5% |- |[[Anglican Church of Canada|Anglican]] |align="right"|2,060,720 |align="right"|14.7% |- |[[Presbyterian Church in Canada|Presbyterian]] |align="right"|781,747 |align="right"|5.6% |- |[[Baptists in Canada|Baptist]] |align="right"|519,585 |align="right"|3.7% |- |[[Lutheranism|Lutheran]] |align="right"|444,923 |align="right"|3.2% |- |[[Judaism in Canada|Jewish]] |align="right"|204,836 |align="right"|1.5% |- |[[Ukrainian Catholic Archeparchy of Winnipeg|Ukrainian (Greek) Catholic]] |align="right"|190,831 |align="right"|1.4% |- |[[Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Canada|Greek Orthodox]] |align="right"|172,271 |align="right"|1.2% |- |[[Mennonite Church Canada|Mennonite]] |align="right"|125,938 |align="right"|0.9% |- |[[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal]] |align="right"|95,131 |align="right"|0.7% |- |[[The Salvation Army, Canada|Salvation Army]] |align="right"|70,275 |align="right"|0.5% |- |[[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] |align="right"|50,900 |align="right"|0.4% |- |[[Jehovah's Witnesses]] |align="right"|34,596 |align="right"|0.2% |- |[[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Canada|Mormon]] |align="right"|32,888 |align="right"|0.2% |- |[[Irreligion|No religion]] |align="right"|59,679 |align="right"|0.4% |- |Other/not recorded |align="right"|260,625 |align="right"|1.9% |} In 1919–20 Canada's five major [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denominations ([[Anglicanism|Anglican]], [[Baptism|Baptist]], [[Congregational church|Congregational]], [[Methodism|Methodist]], and [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]]) cooperatively undertook the "Forward Movement." The goal was to raise funds and to strengthen [[Christianity|Christian spirituality]] in Canada. The movement invoked [[English language|Anglophone]] nationalism by linking donations with the [[Canada Savings Bond#World War I|Victory Loan campaigns]] of the [[First World War]], and stressed the need for funds to [[Culture of Canada|Canadianize]] immigrants. Centred in [[Ontario]], the campaign was a clear financial success, raising over $11 million. However the campaign exposed deep divisions among Protestants, with the traditional [[Evangelism|Evangelists]] speaking of a personal relationship with [[God]] and the more liberal denominations emphasizing the [[Social Gospel]] and [[good works]].Daryl Baswick, "Social Evangelism, the Canadian Churches, and the Forward Movement, 1919–1920," ''Ontario History'' vol 12#1 1997, pp 303–319 Both factions (apart from the Anglicans) agreed on prohibition, which was demanded by the [[WCTU]].Sharon Anne Cook, "'Earnest Christian Women, Bent on Saving our Canadian Youth': The Ontario Woman's Christian Temperance Union and Scientific Temperance Instruction, 1881–1930," ''Ontario History,'' Sept 1994, Vol. 86 Issue 3, pp 249–267 As of 1931, Roman Catholics were the largest religious body in Canada, with 4 million people. Following it were the United Church of Canada (including Methodists, Congregationalists and Presbyterians), with 2 million; the Anglican Church, with nearly 2 million; and the Presbyterian Church, with approximately 870,000. The Canada Year Book 1936 reported that "of the non-Christian sects, 155,614 or 1.50% were Jews, 24,087 or 0.23% were Confucians, 15,784 or 0.15% were Buddhists and 5,008 or 0.05% were pagans.{{cite web|url=http://www65.statcan.gc.ca/acyb07/acyb07_0009-eng.htm|title=Canada Year Book (CYB) Historical Collection|first=Statistics|last=Canada|website=www65.statcan.gc.ca}} Domination of Canadian society by Protestant and Roman Catholic elements continued until well into the 20th century. Until the 1960s, most parts of Canada still had extensive [[Blue law|Lord's Day]] laws that limited what one could do on a Sunday.{{cite book|author=Alvin J. Schmidt|title=How Christianity Changed the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cmdYNpRDo-gC&pg=PT422|date= 2009|publisher=Zondervan|isbn=978-0-310-86250-5|page=422}} The English Canadian elite were still dominated by Protestants, and [[Judaism|Jews]] and Roman Catholics were often excluded.{{cite book|author=Kari Levitt|title=Silent Surrender: The Multinational Corporation in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ApKvFzegt-sC&pg=PA151|year=2002|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press |isbn=978-0-7735-2311-1|page=151}} A slow process of liberalization began after the [[Second World War]] in English Canada. Overtly Christian laws were expunged, including those against [[homosexuality]]. Policies favouring Christian immigration were also abolished.{{cite book|author=Richard Moon|title=Law and Religious Pluralism in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ah66SQsk4hAC&pg=PA244|year=2008|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-5853-3|page=244}} In 1951, a nationwide census was taken after incorporation of predominantly Protestant province of [[Newfoundland and Labrador]]. According to statistics provided by [[Statistics Canada]], Protestants held a slight majority in the country between 1871 and 1961. Despite Canada's large Roman Catholic population, this fact is confirmed by nine consecutive national censuses. By 1961, Roman Catholics overtook Protestants as the most numerous religious group, although—unlike Protestants—they never reached the absolute majority status (>50%). ===1960s and after=== The most overwhelming change occurred during the [[Quiet Revolution]] in [[Quebec]] in the 1960s. Up to the 1950s, the province was one of the most traditional [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] areas in the world. Church attendance rates were high, and the schools were largely controlled by the Church. In the 1960s, the Catholic Church lost most of its influence in Quebec, and religiosity declined sharply.{{cite web |url= http://berkleycenter.georgetown.edu/resources/countries/canada |title=Canada |work= |publisher=[[Berkley Center for Religion, Peace, and World Affairs]] |accessdate=December 12, 2011}} See drop-down essay on "History Since 1960" While the majority of Québécois are still professed Latin rite Roman Catholics, rates of church attendance have decreased dramatically.{{cite book|author=Robin Gill|title=The Empty Church Revisited|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=diCR1O9jnjYC&pg=PA210|year=2003|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-3463-8|page=210}} Since then, [[Common law]] relationships, [[abortion]], and support for [[same-sex marriage]] are more common in Quebec than in the [[English Canada|rest of Canada]]. [[File:United Church of Canada inauguration 1925.jpg|right|thumb|Inauguration of [[United Church]] at Mutual Street Arena, [[Toronto]], on June 10, 1925.]] English Canada also underwent [[Secularity|secularization]]. The [[United Church of Canada]], the country's largest [[Protestantism|Protestant]] denomination, became one of the most liberal major Protestant churches in the world. Flatt argues that in the 1960s Canada's rapid cultural changes led the United Church to end its [[Evangelicalism|evangelical]] programs and change its identity. It made revolutionary changes in its evangelistic campaigns, educational programs, moral stances, and theological image. However, membership declined sharply as the United Church affirmed a commitment to gay rights including marriage and ordination, and to the ordination of women.{{cite book|author=Earle E. Cairns|title=Christianity Through the Centuries: A History of the Christian Church|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G3Kb3rPreUgC&pg=PA507|year=1996|publisher=Zondervan Pub.|isbn=978-0-310-20812-9|page=507}}Kevin N. Flatt, ''After Evangelicalism: The Sixties and the United Church of Canada'' (2013) In 1971, Canada was 47% Catholic, 41% Protestant, 4% Other Religion and 4% Unaffilliated. Meanwhile, a strong current of evangelical Protestantism emerged. The largest groups are found in the [[Atlantic Canada|Atlantic provinces]] and [[Western Canada]], particularly in [[Alberta]], Southern [[Manitoba]] and the Southern interior and [[Fraser Valley]] region of [[British Columbia]], also known as the "Canadian Bible Belt", as well as parts of [[Ontario]] outside the [[Greater Toronto Area]]. The social environment is more conservative, somewhat more in line with that of the [[Midwestern United States|Midwestern]] and [[Southern United States]], and same-sex marriage, abortion, and common-law relationships are less widely accepted. This movement has grown sharply after 1960. The evangelicals increasingly influence public policy. Nevertheless, the overall proportion of evangelicals in Canada remains considerably lower than in the United States and the polarization much less intense. There are very few evangelicals in Quebec and in the largest urban areas, which are generally secular, although there are several congregations above 1000 members in most large cities.{{cite book|author=George A. Rawlyk|title=Aspects of the Canadian Evangelical Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N1c_3TggbrcC&pg=PP1|year=1997|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=978-0-7735-1547-5|page=passim}} ==Abrahamic religions== ===Bahá'í Faith=== [[File:Montreal Bahá'í Shrine.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Montreal]] [[Bahá'í]] [[Shrine]].]] {{Main|Bahá'í Faith in North America#Canada}} The Canadian community is one of the earliest western communities of Bahá'ís, at one point sharing a joint National Spiritual Assembly with the United States, and is a co-recipient of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]]'s [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]. The first North American woman to declare herself a Bahá'í was Kate C. Ives, of Canadian ancestry, though not living in Canada at the time. Moojan Momen, in reviewing "The Origins of the Bahá'í Community of Canada, 1898–1948" notes that "the Magee family... are credited with bringing the Bahá'í Faith to Canada. Edith Magee became a Bahá'í in 1898 in Chicago and returned to her home in London, Ontario, where four other female members of her family became Bahá'ís. This predominance of women converts became a feature of the Canadian Bahá'í community..."{{cite web|url=http://bahai-library.com/momen_hoonaard_origins_bahai |title=Origins of the Baha'i Community of Canada 1898–1948, The, by Will C. van den Hoonaard |publisher=Bahai-library.com |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} === Christianity === {{Further|Christianity in Canada}} The majority of Canadian Christians attend [[church service]]s infrequently. Cross-national surveys of religiosity rates such as the Pew Global Attitudes Project indicate that, on average, Canadian Christians are less observant than those of the United States but are still more overtly religious than their counterparts in Western Europe. In 2002, 30% of Canadians reported to Pew researchers that religion was "very important" to them. A 2005 Gallup poll showed that 28% of Canadians consider religion to be "very important" (55% of Americans and 19% of Britons say the same).{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/20986/Can-Reagan-Revolution-Happen-Canada.aspx |title=Can a "Reagan Revolution" Happen in Canada? |publisher=Gallup.com |date=January 20, 2006 |accessdate=December 10, 2010}} Regional differences within Canada exist, however, with [[British Columbia]] and [[Quebec]] reporting especially low metrics of traditional religious observance, as well as a significant urban-rural divide, while [[Alberta]] and rural [[Ontario]] saw high rates of religious attendance. The rates for weekly church attendance are contested, with estimates running as low as 11% as per the latest Ipsos-Reid poll and as high as 25% as per ''[[Christianity Today]]'' magazine. This American magazine reported that three polls conducted by [[Focus on the Family]], Time Canada and the Vanier Institute of the Family showed church attendance increasing for the first time in a generation, with weekly attendance at 25 per cent. This number is similar to the statistics reported by premier Canadian sociologist of religion, Prof. [[Reginald Bibby]] of the [[University of Lethbridge]], who has been studying Canadian religious patterns since 1975. Although lower than in the US, which has reported weekly church attendance at about 40% since the Second World War, weekly church attendance rates are higher than those in Northern Europe. As well as the large churches – Roman Catholic, United, and Anglican, which together count more than half of the Canadian population as nominal adherents – Canada also has many smaller Christian groups, including [[Orthodox Christianity]]. The Egyptian population in [[Ontario]] and [[Quebec]] ([[Greater Toronto]] in particular) has seen a large influx of the [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodox]] population in just a few decades. The relatively large [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] population of [[Manitoba]] and [[Saskatchewan]] has produced many followers of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Catholic]] and [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Canada|Ukrainian Orthodox Churches]], while southern Manitoba has been settled largely by Mennonites. The concentration of these smaller groups often varies greatly across the country. Baptists are especially numerous in the [[Canadian Maritimes|Maritimes]]. The Maritimes, prairie provinces, and [[southwestern Ontario]] have significant numbers of [[Lutherans]]. Southwest [[Ontario]] has seen large numbers of German and Russian immigrants, including many [[Mennonites]] and [[Hutterites]], as well as a significant contingent of Dutch Reformed. [[Alberta]] has seen considerable immigration from the American plains, creating a significant [[Mormon]] minority in that province. [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] claimed to have 178,102 members (74,377 of whom in Alberta) at the end of 2007.[http://newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/canada-alberta Alberta] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216024628/http://newsroom.lds.org/ldsnewsroom/eng/contact-us/canada-alberta |date=December 16, 2008 }}. LDS Newsroom. And according to the [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] year report there are 111,963 active members (members who actively preach) in Canada. Canada as a nation is becoming increasingly religiously diverse, especially in large urban centres such as [[Toronto]], [[Vancouver]], and [[Montreal]], where minority groups and new immigrants who make up the growth in most religious groups congregate. Two significant trends become clear when the current religious landscape is examined closely. One is the loss of ‘secularized' Canadians as active and regular participants in the churches and denominations they grew up in, which were overwhelmingly [[Christian]], while these churches remain a part of Canadians' cultural identity. The other is the increasing presence of ethnically diverse immigration within the religious makeup of the country. [[File:Cardinal Gerald Lacroix.jpg|thumb|[[Gérald Cyprien Lacroix]] is the actual [[catholic]] [[Primate]] of Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.cccb.ca/site/frc/salle-de-presse/5006-update-from-cccb-delegates-attending-the-synod-of-bishops-on-young-people-the-faith-and-vocational-discernment|title=Conférence des évêques catholiques du Canada - Nouvelles des délégués de la CECC qui participent au Synode des évêques sur les jeunes, la foi et le discernement vocationnel|website=www.cccb.ca|accessdate=November 13, 2018}}]] As Mainline [[Protestant]]s and [[Roman Catholic]]s have experienced drastic losses over the past 30 years, others have been expanding rapidly: overall by 144% in ‘Eastern' religions during the 1981–1991 decade.Roger O'Toole, "Religion in Canada: Its Development and Contemporary Situation" In Lori Beaman, ed., Religion and Canadian Society: Traditions, Transitions, and Innovations. (Toronto: Canadian Scholars' Press, 2006), 18. Considering Canada's increasing reliance on immigration to bolster a low birth rate, the situation is only likely to continue to diversify. This increased influx of ethnic immigrants not only affects the types of religions represented in the Canadian context but also the increasingly multicultural and multilingual makeup of individual Christian denominations. From [[Chinese people|Chinese]] [[Anglican]] or [[South Korea|Korean]] [[United Church]] communities, to the [[Lutheran]] focus on providing much needed services to immigrants new to the Canadian context and [[English language]], immigration is making changes.{{cite book|author1=Paul A. Bramadat|author2=David Seljak|title=Christianity and Ethnicity in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z4HzXN4HQkQC&pg=PP268|year=2008|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=978-0-8020-9584-8|page=268}} For some Protestant [[Christian denomination|denominations]], adapting to a new [[secular]] context has meant adjusting to their non-institutional roles in society by increasingly focusing on [[social justice]].Roger O'Toole, "Religion in Canada: Its Development and Contemporary Situation" In Lori Beaman, ed., Religion and Canadian Society: Traditions, Transitions, and Innovations. (Toronto: Canadian Scholars' Press, 2006), 13–14. However the pull between conservative religious members and the more radical among the church members is complicated by the numbers of immigrant communities who may desire a church that fulfils a more ‘institutionally complete' role as a buffer in this new country over the current tension filled debates over [[same-sex marriage]], [[ordination]] of women and homosexuals, or the role of women in the church. This of course will depend on the background of the immigrant population, as in the [[Hong Kong]] context where [[ordination]] of [[Florence Li Tim Oi]] happened long before women's ordination was ever raised on the Canadian [[Anglican]] church level.Wendy Fletcher, "Canadian Anglicanism and Ethnicity" In P. Bramadat & D. Seljak, Christianity and Ethnicity in Canada. (Toronto: Pearson Longman, 2005.), 156. As well a [[multicultural]] focus on the churches part may include non-Christian elements (such as the inclusion of a [[Buddhist]] priest in one incident) which are unwelcome to the transplanted religious community.Greer Anne Wenh-In Ng, "The United Church of Canada: A Church Fittingly National" In P. Bramadat & D. Seljak, Christianity and Ethnicity in Canada. (Toronto: Pearson Longman, 2005), 232. Serving the needs and desires of different aspects of the Canadian and newly Canadian populations makes a difficult balancing act for the various mainline churches which are starved for money and active parishioners in a time when 16% of Canadians identify as non-religious and up to two-thirds of those who do identify with a denomination use the church only for its life-cycle rituals governing birth, marriage, and death.{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.ca/english/census01/Products/Analytic/companion/rel/canada.cfm |title=96F0030XIE2001015 – Religions in Canada |publisher=2.statcan.ca |accessdate=December 10, 2010}} The church retains that hold in their [[parishioner]]s' lives but not the commitment of time and energy necessary to support an aging institution. [[Evangelical]] portions of the Protestant groups proclaim their growth as well but as Roger O'Tool notes they make up 7% of the Canadian population and seem to gain most of their growth from a higher birthrate.Roger O'Toole, "Religion in Canada: Its Development and Contemporary Situation" In Lori Beaman, ed., Religion and Canadian Society: Traditions, Transitions, and Innovations. (Toronto: Canadian Scholars' Press, 2006), 17. What is significant is the higher participation of their members in contrast to Mainline [[Protestant]]s and [[Roman Catholic]]s. This high commitment would seem to translate into the kind of political power evangelicals in the United States enjoy but despite Canada's historically [[Christian]] background as Lori Beaman notes neatly "...[forming] the backdrop for social process"Lori Beaman, ed., Religion and Canadian Society: Traditions, Transitions, and Innovations. (Toronto: Canadian Scholars' Press, 2006), 3. explicit religiosity appears to have not effectively moved the government towards legal discrimination against gay marriage. Much as many Roman Catholics in [[Quebec]] ignore the Church's stance on [[birth control]], [[abortion]], or [[premarital sex]], the churches do not dictate much of the daily lives of regular Canadians.Roger O'Toole, "Religion in Canada: Its Development and Contemporary Situation" In Lori Beaman, ed., Religion and Canadian Society: Traditions, Transitions, and Innovations. (Toronto: Canadian Scholars' Press, 2006), 12. [[File:Percent Christians per Canadian Province gradient map (2011).svg|thumb|[[Percentage]] of Canadians identifying as Christian by province or territory.]] There was a major religious revival in Toronto in the nineties known as the [[Toronto Blessing]] at a small [[Vineyard Church]] near the [[Toronto Pearson International Airport]]. This religious event was the largest tourist attraction to Toronto{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2014/march-web-only/enduring-revival.html|title=Christianity Today- The Enduring Revival|last=|first=|date=|website=www.google.com|publisher=|access-date=November 6, 2016}} in the year 1994. This event was characterized by unusual religious ecstascy such as being [[slain in the Spirit]], [[Holy laughter|laughing uncontrollably]], and other odd behavior. A 2015 study estimates some 43,000 believers in Christ from a Muslim background in Canada, most of whom belong to the evangelical tradition.{{cite journal|last1=Miller|first1=Duane|last2=Johnstone|first2=Patrick|title=Believers in Christ from a Muslim Background: A Global Census|journal=IJRR|date=2015|volume=11|issue=10|url=https://www.academia.edu/16338087/Believers_in_Christ_from_a_Muslim_Background_A_Global_Census|accessdate=February 14, 2016}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Province/Territory
!! Christians{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/dt-td/Rp-eng.cfm?LANG=E&APATH=3&DETAIL=0&DIM=0&FL=A&FREE=0&GC=0&GID=0&GK=0&GRP=0&PID=105399&PRID=0&PTYPE=105277&S=0&SHOWALL=0&SUB=0&Temporal=2013&THEME=95&VID=0 |title=Religions in Canada—Census 2011 |publisher=Statistics Canada/Statistique Canada}} |- | {{Flag|Newfoundland and Labrador}} || 93.19% |- | {{Flag|Nunavut}} || 85.99% |- | {{Flag|Prince Edward Island}} || 84.16% |- | {{Flag|New Brunswick}} || 83.84% |- | {{Flag|Quebec}} || 82.27% |- | {{Flag|Nova Scotia}} || 78.19% |- | {{Flag|Saskatchewan}} || 72.06% |- | {{Flag|Manitoba}} || 68.43% |- | style="background:silver" | {{Flag|Canada}} || style="background:silver" | 67.30% |- | {{Flag|Northwest Territories}} || 66.30% |- | {{Flag|Ontario}} || 64.55% |- | {{Flag|Alberta}} || 60.32% |- | {{Flag|Yukon}} || 46.16% |- | {{Flag|British Columbia}} || 44.64% |} ==== Anabaptism ==== {{Main|Anabaptists}} ===== Hutterites ===== [[File:Hutterer-Neue Kolonie.jpg|thumb|right|A Hutterite colony in [[Manitoba]].]] {{Main|Hutterite}} In mid-1870s Hutterites moved from Europe to the [[Dakota Territory]] in the United States to avoid military service and other persecutions.[http://www.hutterites.org/history/journey-to-america/ Journey to America], Hutterian Brethren. Retrieved April 25, 2014 During [[World War I]] Hutterites suffered from persecutions in the United States because they are pacifist and refused military service.Smith, C. Henry (1981). Smith's Story of the Mennonites (Revised and expanded by Cornelius Krahn ed.). Newton, Kansas: Faith and Life Press. p. 545. {{ISBN|0-87303-069-9}}. They then moved almost all of their communities to Canada in the Western provinces of Alberta and Manitoba in 1918.[http://www.hutterites.org/history/world-war-1/ World War 1], Hutterian Brethren. Retrieved April 25, 2014 In the 1940s, there were 52 Hutterite colonies in Canada. Today, more than 75% of the world's Hutterite colonies are located in Canada, mainly in Alberta, Manitoba and Saskatchewan, the rest being almost exclusively in the United States.[http://www.cedrontech.com/directory/ A directory of Hutterite colonies]. Retrieved on April 25, 2014 The Hutterite population in North America is about 45,000 people.[http://www.hutterites.org/history/ww1-beyond/ WW1 & Beyond], Hutterian Brethren. Retrieved April 25, 2014 ===== Mennonites ===== {{Main|Mennonite Church Canada}} First Mennonites arrived in Canada in 1786 from [[Pennsylvania]], but following Mennonites arrived directly from Europe.{{cite book|author=National Council of Ch of Christ in USA|title=Yearbook of American & Canadian Churches 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5DWeLz28b88C&pg=PT406|year=2012|publisher=Abingdon Press|isbn=978-1-4267-5610-8|pages=406–}} The [[Mennonite Church Canada]] had about 35,000 members in 1998.{{cite book|author=Donald B. Kraybill|title=Concise Encyclopedia of Amish, Brethren, Hutterites, and Mennonites|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-fYQjwmOafoC&pg=PA54|year=2010|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-9911-9|page=54}} ==== The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints ==== [[File:Cardston Alberta Canada Temple.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Cardston Alberta Temple]], the oldest [[Latter Day Saint movement|LDS]] temple outside the United States.]] {{Main|The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Canada}} [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) has had a presence in Canada since its organization in New York State in 1830.{{cite book|author=Brigham Young Card|title=The Mormon Presence in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GY4D9JhK69wC&pg=PA19|year=1990|publisher=University of Alberta|isbn=978-0-88864-212-7|page=19}} Canada has been used as a refuge territory by members of the LDS Church to avoid the anti-polygamy prosecutions by the United States government.{{cite book|author=Paul Finkelman|title=Encyclopedia of American Civil Liberties|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TXoKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1039|year=2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-94705-7|page=1039}} The first LDS Church in Canada was established in 1895 in what would become Alberta; it was the first stake of the Church to be established outside the United States.{{cite book|author=Liz Bryan|title=Country Roads of Alberta: Exploring the Routes Less Travelled|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e_Mr62z2ba4C&pg=PT82|year=2011|publisher=Heritage House|isbn=978-1-926613-02-4|page=82}} The LDS Church has founded several communities in Alberta. In 2011, the LDS Church of Canada claimed around 200,000 members; the 2011 Canadian National Household Survey calculates around 100,000.{{cite web|title=2011 National Household Survey|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/dt-td/Rp-eng.cfm?LANG=E&APATH=3&DETAIL=0&DIM=0&FL=A&FREE=0&GC=0&GID=0&GK=0&GRP=0&PID=105399&PRID=0&PTYPE=105277&S=0&SHOWALL=0&SUB=0&Temporal=2013&THEME=95&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=|publisher=Statistics Canada|accessdate=February 3, 2016}} It has congregations in all Canadian provinces and territories and possess at least one temple in six of the ten provinces, including the oldest LDS temple outside the United States. Alberta is the province with the most members of the LDS Church in Canada, having approximately 40% of the total of Canadian LDS Church members and representing 2% of the total population of the province (the National Household survey has Alberta with over 50% of the Canadian Mormons and 1.6% of the province's population), followed by Ontario and British Columbia.''Deseret News Church Almanac, 2011'' ==== Roman Catholicism ==== {{Main|Roman Catholicism in Canada}} [[File:St John's Basilica.jpg |thumb|Front of the [[Basilica of St. John the Baptist]] in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], [[Newfoundland]].]] The Catholic Church in Canada, under the spiritual leadership of the Pope and the [[Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops]]{{cite web|url=https://www.cccb.ca|title=CECC / CCCB|website=www.cccb.ca|accessdate=November 13, 2018}}, has the largest number of adherents to a religion in Canada, with 38.7% of Canadians (13.07 million) reported as Catholics in the 2011 National Household Survey, in 72 [[list of Roman Catholic dioceses in Canada|dioceses]] across the provinces and territories, served by about 8,000 priests. It was the first European faith in what is now Canada, arriving in 1497 when [[John Cabot]] landed on [[Island of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]] and raised the Venetian and Papal banners, claiming the land for his sponsor King [[Henry VII of England]], while recognizing the religious authority of the Roman Catholic Church.P D'Epiro, M.D. Pinkowish, "Sprezzatura: 50 ways Italian genius shaped the world" pp. 179–180 The entire Catholic Church in Canada is placed under the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Quebec#Primate of Canada|Primate of Canada]]{{cite web|url=https://www.catholicanada.com/2018/07/16/homily-by-cardinal-gerald-cyprien-lacroix-archbishop-of-quebec-primate-of-canada/|title=Homily by Cardinal Gérald Cyprien Lacroix Archbishop of Quebec Primate of Canada|website=www.catholicanada.com|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} which corresponds to the [[Archdiocese of Quebec]] and is bishop, the Primate of Canada. Actually, [[Gérald Cyprien Lacroix]] is the Primate of Canada. The [[Pope]] is represented in Canada by the [[Apostolic Nunciature in Canada]] ([[Ottawa]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.nuntiatura.ca|title=Apostolic Nunciature in Canada - Nonciature Apostolique au Canada|website=www.nuntiatura.ca|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} ====Anglican Church of Canada==== [[Anglican Church of Canada]] is the only official church of the [[Anglican Communion in Canada]].{{cite web|url=https://www.anglican.ca|title=Welcome to the Anglican Church of Canada|website=The Anglican Church of Canada|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} Across Canada there are approximately 1,700 individual [[church (congregation)|church]]es or [[parishes]], which are organized into 30 different [[dioceses]], each led by a [[bishop]]. The national church office is known as [[General Synod]].{{cite web|url=https://www.anglican.ca/about/organization/|title=How we are organized - The Anglican Church of Canada|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} The Primate is the Archbishop Fred Hiltz, national pastoral leader. ==== Eastern Orthodox Christianity ==== {{Main|Eastern Orthodoxy in North America}} Adherents of [[Eastern Orthodox]] Christianity in Canada belong to several ecclesiastical jurisdictions. Historically, Eastern Orthodoxy was introduced to Canada during the course of 19th century, mainly through emigration of Christians from [[Eastern Europe]] and the [[Middle East]]. Honoring such diverse heritage, Eastern Orthodoxy in Canada is traditionally organized in accordance with patrimonial jurisdictions of [[autocephalous]] Eastern Orthodox Churches, each of them having its own hierarchy with dioceses and parishes. According to 2011 census data, [[Greek Orthodox]] community constitutes the largest Eastern Orthodox community in Canada, with 220,255 adherents. It is followed by other communities: Russian Orthodox (25,245), Ukrainian Orthodox (23,845), [[Serbian Orthodox Eparchy of Canada|Serbian Orthodox]] (22,780), [[Romanian Orthodox Eparchy of Canada|Romanian Orthodox]] (7,090), [[Macedonian Orthodox Eparchy of America and Canada|Macedonian Orthodox]] (4,945), [[Bulgarian Eastern Orthodox Diocese of the USA, Canada and Australia|Bulgarian Orthodox]] (1,765), [[Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese of North America|Antiochian Orthodox]] (1,220) and several other minor communities within Eastern Orthodoxy.{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/dt-td/Rp-eng.cfm?LANG=E&APATH=3&DETAIL=0&DIM=0&FL=A&FREE=0&GC=0&GID=0&GK=0&GRP=1&PID=105399&PRID=0&PTYPE=105277&S=0&SHOWALL=0&SUB=0&Temporal=2013&THEME=95&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=|title=2011 National Household Survey: Data tables – Religion (108), Immigrant Status and Period of Immigration (11), Age Groups (10) and Sex (3) for the Population in Private Households of Canada, Provinces, Territories, Census Metropolitan Areas and Census Agglomerations, 2011 National Household Survey|first=Government of Canada, Statistics|last=Canada|website=www12.statcan.gc.ca}} ==== Oriental Orthodox Christianity ==== {{main|Oriental Orthodoxy in North America}} Adherents of [[Oriental Orthodox]] Christianity in Canada also belong to several ethnic communities and ecclesiastical jurisdictions. According to 2011 census data, [[Coptic Orthodox Church in Canada|Coptic Orthodox]] community constitutes the largest Oriental Orthodox community in Canada, with 16,255 adherents. It is followed by other communities: Armenian Orthodox (13,730), Ethiopian Orthodox (3,025), Syriac Orthodox (3,060) and several other minor communities within Oriental Orthodoxy. ===Islam=== {{Further|Islam in Canada}} [[File:Gatineau Mosque .IMG 4651.jpg|right|thumb|Gatineau Mosque in [[Quebec]].]] Four years after Canada's founding in 1867, the 1871 Canadian Census found 13 Muslims among the population.1871 Census of Canada Today, [[Islam]] is the second largest religion in Canada, practised by 3.2% of the total population. The first Canadian [[mosque]] was constructed in [[Edmonton, Alberta|Edmonton]] in 1938, when there were approximately 700 Muslims in the country.Saudi Aramco World: Canada's Pioneer Mosque: http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/199804/canada.s.pioneer.mosque.htm This building is now part of the museum at [[Fort Edmonton Park]]. The years after [[World War II]] saw a small increase in the Muslim population. However, Muslims were still a distinct minority. It was only with the removal of European immigration preferences in the late 1960s that Muslims began to arrive in significant numbers. According to [[Canada 2001 Census|Canada's 2001 census]], there were 579,740 [[Muslim]]s in Canada, just under 2% of the population.{{cite web |url=http://www40.statcan.gc.ca/l01/cst01/demo30a-eng.htm?sdi=religion |title=Population by religion, by province and territory (2001 Census) |publisher=0.statcan.gc.ca |accessdate=October 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810201649/http://www40.statcan.gc.ca/l01/cst01/demo30a-eng.htm?sdi=religion |archivedate=August 10, 2011 }} In 2006, the Muslim population was estimated to be 0.8 million or about 2.6%. In 2010, the Pew Research Centre estimated there were about 0.9 million Muslims in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://features.pewforum.org/muslim-population/?sort=Pop2010 |title=World Muslim Population Data Tables – Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life |publisher=Features.pewforum.org |accessdate=October 17, 2012}} About 65% were Sunni, while 15% were Shia.{{dead link|date=July 2013}}http://www.environicsinstitute.org/PDF-MuslimsandMulticulturalisminCanada-LiftingtheVeil.pdf – Muslims and Multiculturalism in Canada. March 2007. Retrieved March 26, 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127182349/http://www.environicsinstitute.org/PDF-MuslimsandMulticulturalisminCanada-LiftingtheVeil.pdf |date=January 27, 2012 }} In the 2011 National Housing Survey, Muslims constituted 3.2% of the population{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/05/08/survey-shows-muslim-population-is-fastest-growing-religion-in-canada/ |title=Muslims fastest growing religious population in Canada | National Post |publisher=News.nationalpost.com |accessdate=July 14, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/130508/dq130508b-eng.htm?HPA |title=The Daily – 2011 National Household Survey: Immigration, place of birth, citizenship, ethnic origin, visible minorities, language and religion |publisher=Statcan.gc.ca |date=May 9, 2013 |accessdate=July 14, 2013}} making them largest religious adherents after Christianity. Islam is the fastest growing religion in Canada. Sunni Islam is followed by the majority while there are significant numbers of Shia Muslims. Ahmadiyya also has a significant proportion with more than 25,000 [[Ahmadiyya|Ahmadis]] living in Canada.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dgtgGhMUgIUC&lpg=PA73&pg=PA73#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Asian Religions in British Columbia | accessdate=April 6, 2014 | date=August 9, 2012 |page=73 |author1=Don Baker |author2=Daniel L. Overmyer |author3=Larry DeVries | publisher=UCB Press}} There are also [[non-denominational Muslims]]Pew Forum on Religious & Public life. August 9, 2012. Retrieved October 29, 2013 In 2007, the [[CBC Television|CBC]] introduced a popular television sitcom called ''[[Little Mosque on the Prairie]]'', a contemporary reflection and critical commentary on attitudes towards [[Islam]] in Canada.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/littlemosque/ |title=CBC Television – Little Mosque on the Prairie |publisher=Cbc.ca |accessdate=December 10, 2010}} In 2008, the Prime Minister of Canada, [[Stephen Harper]], visited the [[Baitun Nur]] Mosque, the largest mosque in Canada for its inaugural session with the Head of the [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]].{{cite news |url=http://www.canada.com/topics/news/story.html?id=c1ce5c3b-de23-4093-85b8-36162ac636a6 |title=Politicians and faithful open Canada's largest mosque |last=Morton |first=Graeme |work=Canada.com |publisher=Canwest News Service |date=July 5, 2008 |accessdate=July 12, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012150130/http://www.canada.com/topics/news/story.html?id=c1ce5c3b-de23-4093-85b8-36162ac636a6 |archivedate=October 12, 2008 }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Province/Territory
